doc: <title>Behavioral markers for crew resource management: A review of current practice</title> <excerpt>Developments in crew resource management (CRM) have progressed from the introduction of training programs to the evaluation of CRM skills, particularly for multicrew cockpits. European regulators responsible for flight operations and flight crew licensing (Joint Aviation Authorities, 1996, 1997) are introducing requirements for the training and assessment of pilots' nontechnical skills. This article reports a review of the literature and a survey of current practice in the development and use of behavioral marker systems for training and assessing nontechnical CRM skills in international and domestic (UK) airlines.</excerpt>

title: To transfer or not to transfer? Investigating the combined effects of trainee characteristics, team leader support, and team climate
doc: <title>To transfer or not to transfer? Investigating the combined effects of trainee characteristics, team leader support, and team climate</title> <excerpt>Eighty pilots participated in a study of variables influencing the transfer process. Posttraining performance was assessed in a flight simulation under 1 of 2 conditions. Those in the maximum performance condition were made aware of the skill to be assessed and the fact that their teammates were confederates, whereas those in the typical performance condition were not.</excerpt>

title: A non-traditional approach to understanding total system performance of avionics systems
doc: <title>A non-traditional approach to understanding total system performance of avionics systems</title> <excerpt>On the next military combat mission, space shuttle flight, or mission to Mars think of what it would be like if R2-D2, Luke Skywalker's backseater in his X-wing fighter, was along for the mission. In the movie, Star Wars, R2-D2 had both intelligence and personality. If we were to design a real R2-D2 (eg, an automated aviation assistant, a synthetic crewmember, a computerized co-pilot, or a 'Pilot's Associate') for the next generation of avionics, what personality characteristics should we give it? We know that personality effects behavior and as a result affects how we see problems and subsequently, solve them.</excerpt>

title: The West London Schools Study: the effects of chronic aircraft noise exposure on child health
doc: <title>The West London Schools Study: the effects of chronic aircraft noise exposure on child health</title> <excerpt>Background. Previous field studies have indicated that children's cognitive performance is impaired by chronic aircraft noise exposure. However, these studies have not been of sufficient size to account adequately for the role of confounding factors.</excerpt>

title: Sharing ‘worlds of risk’; improving communication with crew resource management
doc: <title>Sharing ‘worlds of risk’; improving communication with crew resource management</title> <excerpt>In recent years, increasing emphasis has been placed on the role of context and culture in shaping both the perception and experience of risk. Evidence from a number of industrial psychology studies indicates that workers’ perceptions of risk are influenced by the context and culture of their work environment, leading to different ‘worlds of risk’ between professional groups and levels of seniority within the work organization. If perception of risk and safety is not a unified phenomenon within organizational settings, how does one achieve the ‘shared attitudes, perceptions and beliefs with respect to risk and safety’ which are considered fundamental to the development and propagation of a good safety culture? Safety is a dynamic phenomenon that requires continual monitoring from a number of different perspectives in order to prevent incidents.</excerpt>

title: Human factors training - A contribution to increase aviation safety; Human factors training - Ein beitrag zur eurhöhung der sicherheit im luftverkehr
doc: <title>Human factors training - A contribution to increase aviation safety; Human factors training - Ein beitrag zur eurhöhung der sicherheit im luftverkehr</title> <excerpt>The international airlines business is well-known for its high level of safety standards. One predominant reason for this might be seen in the fact that all people employed in this field are continuously-trained by sophisticated programs. The paper describes one of Lufthansa's non-technical skills training, the so-called "Crew Resource Management Training" (CRM), which is mandatory for all cockpit and cabin crew members.</excerpt>

title: Visual flight rules flight into instrument meteorological conditions: An empirical investigation of the possible causes
doc: <title>Visual flight rules flight into instrument meteorological conditions: An empirical investigation of the possible causes</title> <excerpt>Pilots' decisions to continue or divert from a visual flight rules (VFR) flight into instrument meteorological conditions (IMC) were investigated using a dynamic simulation of a hypothetical cross-country flight. Differences in situation assessment, risk perception, and motivation between pilots who chose to continue or divert from a VFR flight into an IMC situation were examined. Results indicate that the simulation was successful in identifying pilots who would choose to either continue or divert and that differences existed between these two groups of pilots.</excerpt>

title: Control study of personality characteristics and variation of plasma peptide in pilots with neurosis
doc: <title>Control study of personality characteristics and variation of plasma peptide in pilots with neurosis</title>

title: Does Learning a Complex Task Have to Be Complex?: A Study in Learning Decomposition
doc: <title>Does Learning a Complex Task Have to Be Complex?: A Study in Learning Decomposition</title> <excerpt>Many theories of skill acquisition have had considerable success in addressing the fine details of learning in relatively simple tasks, but can they scale up to complex tasks that are more typical of human learning in the real world? Some theories argue for scalability by making the implicit assumption that complex tasks consist of many smaller parts, which are learned according to basic learning principles. Surprisingly, there has been rather sparse empirical testing of this crucial assumption. In this article, we examine this assumption directly by decomposing the learning in the Kanfer-Ackerman Air-Traffic Controller Task (Ackerman, 1988) from the learning at the global level all the way down to the learning at the keystroke level.</excerpt>

title: Psychological aspects of training for and implementation of a piloted expedition to Mars; Psikhologicheskie aspekty podgotovki i osushchestvleniia pilotiruemoi ékspeditsii na Mars.
doc: <title>Psychological aspects of training for and implementation of a piloted expedition to Mars; Psikhologicheskie aspekty podgotovki i osushchestvleniia pilotiruemoi ékspeditsii na Mars.</title> <excerpt>Reviewed are the modern notions of the main psychological concerns regarding a mission to Mars which are maintenance of mental health, high professional reliability, and successful readaptation of the Martian crew on return to Earth. The unprecedent trail-blazing interplanetary mission distinguished by autonomy, long period, international crew and a broad range of tasks to tend will set particularly difficult requirements to the psychological support system. Among them prioritized are purposeful character building and training of future crew members already in childhood and youth.</excerpt>

title: An investigation of task and interpersonal processes supporting women remaining in general aviation flight training
doc: <title>An investigation of task and interpersonal processes supporting women remaining in general aviation flight training</title> <excerpt>Flight training activity in the General Aviation (GA) industry has been in decline for over 20 years with little indication of a turnaround. Flight schools and GA industry groups have identified a need to increase student and training retention as important to improving the health of the GA industry. The GA industry has identified women as a group to market to for increasing flight student and licensed pilots.</excerpt>

title: Chronic aircraft noise exposure, stress responses, mental health and cognitive performance in school children
doc: <title>Chronic aircraft noise exposure, stress responses, mental health and cognitive performance in school children</title> <excerpt>Background. Previous research suggests that children are a high risk group vulnerable to the effects of chronic noise exposure. However, questions remain about the nature of the noise effects and the underlying causal mechanisms.</excerpt>

title: Vertical navigation displays: Pilot performance and workload during simulated constant angle of descent GPS approaches
doc: <title>Vertical navigation displays: Pilot performance and workload during simulated constant angle of descent GPS approaches</title> <excerpt>This study compared the effect of alternative graphic or numeric vertical navigation aircraft cockpit displays on horizontal and vertical flight technical error, workload, and subjective preference. Displays included (a) a moving map with altitude range arc; (b) the same format, supplemented with a push-to-see profile view, including a vector flight-path predictor; (c) an equivalent numeric display; and (d) a numeric nonvertical navigation display. Sixteen pilots each flew 4 different approaches with each format in a Frasca 242 simulator.</excerpt>

title: Major (part 121) United States air carrier implementation of crew resource management training concepts as outlined in the Federal Aviation Administration's Advisory Circular 120 -51C
doc: <title>Major (part 121) United States air carrier implementation of crew resource management training concepts as outlined in the Federal Aviation Administration's Advisory Circular 120 -51C</title> <excerpt>Scope and method of study. The research was conducted to determine the depth of CRM component incorporation as specified in FAA AC 120-51C and the extent of personality trait adaptation in CRM training and the degree of integration of these concepts into normal, flight, operational procedures. A purposeful sample of the population was obtained through strict adherence to an accepted definition of the air transportation industry.</excerpt>

title: Runway width effects in the visual approach to landing
doc: <title>Runway width effects in the visual approach to landing</title> <excerpt>The effect of changes in runway width on the perception of glide-slope has been the subject of extensive investigations. Despite considerable research, an explanation of this effect has been elusive. A mathematical model for glide-slope perception was published recently based on the premise that a desirable goal of perception is to form a perception with minimal uncertainty.</excerpt>

title: Air traffic controller performance and workload under mature free flight: Conflict detection and resolution of aircraft self-separation
doc: <title>Air traffic controller performance and workload under mature free flight: Conflict detection and resolution of aircraft self-separation</title> <excerpt>The effects of conflict detection and self-separating aircraft resolution on the mental workload and performance of en-route air traffic controllers were examined. An air traffic control simulator was used to manipulate traffic loads and traffic complexity. A mature stage of free flight was simulated by having controllers monitor self-separating aircraft.</excerpt>

title: Analysis of job satisfaction, pay, and the career intent of naval aviators
doc: <title>Analysis of job satisfaction, pay, and the career intent of naval aviators</title> <excerpt>Scope and method of study. Much insight can be gained from the study of behavior, motivation and organizational theory in assessing employee job satisfaction, pay satisfaction and commitment to an employer or job. Although the military has been paying Naval Aviators monetary bonuses for many years to retain their services, little to no research has addressed the pay satisfaction of Naval Aviators relative to job satisfaction and career intentions.</excerpt>

title: A controlled study of virtual reality exposure therapy for the fear of flying
doc: <title>A controlled study of virtual reality exposure therapy for the fear of flying</title> <excerpt>Fear of flying (FOF) affects an estimated 10-25% of the population. Patients with FOF (N = 49) were randomly assiged to virtual reality exposure (VRE) therapy, standard exposure (SE) therapy, or a wait-list (WL) control. Treatment consisted of 8 sessions over 6 weeks, with 4 sessions of anxiety management training followed by either exposure to a virtual airplane (VRE) or exposure to an actual airplane at the airport (SE)..</excerpt>

title: The lessons we (don't) learn: Counterfactual thinking and organizational accountability after a close call
doc: <title>The lessons we (don't) learn: Counterfactual thinking and organizational accountability after a close call</title> <excerpt>How individuals learn from imagined might-have-been scenarios is investigated. It is hypothesized that individuals are more likely to learn when they have responded to an event with upward-directed, self-focused counterfactual thoughts, and, additionally, that this learning process is inhibited by accountability to organizational superiors. Support for these hypotheses was obtained in 2 studies that assessed learning by aviation pilots from the experience of near accidents.</excerpt>

title: Tactical displays for combat awareness: An examination of dimensionality and frame of reference concepts and the application of cognitive engineering
doc: <title>Tactical displays for combat awareness: An examination of dimensionality and frame of reference concepts and the application of cognitive engineering</title> <excerpt>Three prototype displays are contrasted for aircraft navigation and tactical hazard awareness: a conventional 2-D coplanar display, an exocentric (God's eye) 3-D display, and an immersed (pilot's eye) 3-D display coupled with a small scale global display. Strengths and weaknesses of each display type are discussed, related particularly to the ambiguity of perspective displays and to attention allocation problems with dual-display suites. In Experiment 1, 8 pilots flew with each of the displays around an airspace populated by waypoints, hazards, and traffic.</excerpt>

title: A cognitive load scale for measuring information management on the general aviation flight deck
doc: <title>A cognitive load scale for measuring information management on the general aviation flight deck</title> <excerpt>An investigation was undertaken to determine whether a previously derived multidimensional organizational solution could be meaningfully converted into a subjective scale for the measurement of the cognitive load associated with the management of information by pilots in the general aviation cockpit. The investigation was in the form of three major groups of tasks, each of which was performed by a separate group of pilots. The first set of tasks involved reanalyzing the original paired-comparisons data to determine the consistency of the previous multidimensional solution.</excerpt>

title: What role does emotional intelligence (EI) play for superior performers in the international business of a capital -intensive, asset-based industry?
doc: <title>What role does emotional intelligence (EI) play for superior performers in the international business of a capital -intensive, asset-based industry?</title> <excerpt>In an increasingly competitive global environment, organizations are showing a renewed interest in how individuals create and sustain organizational capabilities for competitive advantage. This study demonstrates that emotional intelligence competencies are critical to the successful planning and execution of international business in a capital-intensive, asset-based industry. The study's population comprised employees whose responsibilities ranged from idea conceptualization to revenue realization, in a capital-intensive, asset-based, international petroleum company.</excerpt>

title: Multisensory interface design for complex task domains: Replacing information overload with meaning in tactical crew stations
doc: <title>Multisensory interface design for complex task domains: Replacing information overload with meaning in tactical crew stations</title> <excerpt>Modern aerial combat represents a highly complex task domain that imposes many significant challenges on aviators. In modern cockpits there are more sources of dynamic information than any single pilot has the ability to attend to, let alone comprehend, all at once. As technological developments lead to the deployment of new weapons systems, the future aerial battlefield will inevitably yield increased levels of complexity.</excerpt>

title: A study of CEO perceptions of the competencies of workplace learning and performance professionals
doc: <title>A study of CEO perceptions of the competencies of workplace learning and performance professionals</title> <excerpt>The study examined CEO perceptions of competencies for workplace learning and performance professionals. The purpose of the study was to identify the most important abilities of the person responsible for an organization's workplace learning and performance programs. Participants in the study were CEOs in organizations with one thousand or more employees.</excerpt>

title: The company as family: Perceived strengths of Duncan Aviation
doc: <title>The company as family: Perceived strengths of Duncan Aviation</title> <excerpt>In contemporary American society, the boundaries between public and private life are blurring. Both work and non-work domains are now expected to provide psychological and emotional support. These heightened expectations of the workplace emphasize the increasing need for business organizations to have positive and supportive work environments.</excerpt>

title: Paper Dolls and Paper Airplanes: Therapeutic Exercises for Sexually Traumatized Children
doc: <title>Paper Dolls and Paper Airplanes: Therapeutic Exercises for Sexually Traumatized Children</title> <excerpt>Peterson reviews "Paper Dolls and Paper Airplanes: Therapeutic Exercises for Sexually Traumatized Children" by Geraldine Crisci, Marilynn Lay and Liana Lowenstein..</excerpt>

title: Effect of an inhibition testing model on private pilot, airplane single-engine land, ground school students
doc: <title>Effect of an inhibition testing model on private pilot, airplane single-engine land, ground school students</title> <excerpt>Scope and method of study. The purpose of this study was to determine if, and to what extent, a relationship or difference existed between the cognitive context of the classroom and the cognitive context of the aircraft for private pilot students. Subjects were 34 college students from three intact groups of private pilot ground school students from three colleges or universities in Oklahoma.</excerpt>

title: Psychological aspects of human spaceflight: effects on human cognitive, psychomotor, and attentional performance
doc: <title>Psychological aspects of human spaceflight: effects on human cognitive, psychomotor, and attentional performance</title> <excerpt>Since the first human spaceflight into orbit, the space environment has become one of the most extreme working environments for humans. Staying and working in a space habitat is connected with exposure to a lot of different stressors all of which may entail detrimental effects on human performance and psychological well-being of astronauts. However, the psychological impact of the extreme environmental conditions in space and particularly its impact on mental performance of astronauts has only recently become an object of systematic research.</excerpt>

title: Aircrew perceived stress: Examining crew performance, crew position and captains personality
doc: <title>Aircrew perceived stress: Examining crew performance, crew position and captains personality</title> <excerpt>This study was conducted at NASA Ames Research Center as a part of a larger research project assessing the impact of captain's personality on crew performance and perceived stress in 24 air transport crews (5). Three different personality types for captains were classified based on a previous cluster analysis (3). Crews were comprised of three crewmembers: captain, first officer, and second officer/flight engineer.</excerpt>

title: Fear of flying treatment programs for passengers: An international review
doc: <title>Fear of flying treatment programs for passengers: An international review</title> <excerpt>Background: There are facilities established around the world for treating passenger flight anxiety, often as a joint activity of airlines and private entrepreneurs or mental health professionals. In the scientific and professional literature, there is little information about how these facilities operate and what the components of their treatment programs are. This paper is the first review to date to provide this information.</excerpt>

title: Neuropsychological guidelines for aircraft control stations: Applying knowledge of how humans interact in different portions of 3-D space
doc: <title>Neuropsychological guidelines for aircraft control stations: Applying knowledge of how humans interact in different portions of 3-D space</title> <excerpt>Although the abnormal acceleratory environment of flight is inherently dangerous and unforgiving, the poor design of most aviation control stations arguably compounds the sensorimotor limitations of pilots in the aerial environment. A set of guidelines for aircraft control stations based on neuropsychological principles are presented. These stations will exploit fully the information processing capabilities of pilots and allow them to cope better with the demands of flying and enhanced tactical operations..</excerpt>

title: Do we "know" all that we "know"? The role of implicit knowledge in situation awareness
doc: <title>Do we "know" all that we "know"? The role of implicit knowledge in situation awareness</title>

title: Psychological dysadaptation and its psychoprophylaxis in students of higher aviation schools (psychophysiologic aspect); O psikhicheskoi dizadaptatsii i ee psikhoprofilaktike u kursantov letnykh vuzov (Psikhofiziologicheskii aspekt).
doc: <title>Psychological dysadaptation and its psychoprophylaxis in students of higher aviation schools (psychophysiologic aspect); O psikhicheskoi dizadaptatsii i ee psikhoprofilaktike u kursantov letnykh vuzov (Psikhofiziologicheskii aspekt).</title>

title: Analyzing cockpit communications: the links between language, performance, error, and workload.
doc: <title>Analyzing cockpit communications: the links between language, performance, error, and workload.</title> <excerpt>The importance of communication on the flightdeck is discussed and the application of a new computer-based linguistic method of text analysis is introduced. Preliminary results from a NASA B727 simulator study indicate that specific language variables are moderately to highly correlated with individual performance, individual error rates, and individual communication ratings. Also, language use was found to vary as a function of crew position and level of workload during the flight.</excerpt>

title: Coordination of mental health and community agencies in disaster response.
doc: <title>Coordination of mental health and community agencies in disaster response.</title> <excerpt>Within the past 10 years, the American Red Cross has responded to dramatic disasters and terrorist events that have resulted in significant loss of life and traumatic stress responses. These disasters have included events as diverse as earthquakes, explosions, and aviation accidents..</excerpt>

title: The assessment and correction of the body functional state of aviation specialists working with video display terminals; Otsenka i korrektsiia funktsional'nogo sostoianiia organizma aviatsionnykh spetsialistov, rabotaiushchikh s videodispleinymi terminalami.
doc: <title>The assessment and correction of the body functional state of aviation specialists working with video display terminals; Otsenka i korrektsiia funktsional'nogo sostoianiia organizma aviatsionnykh spetsialistov, rabotaiushchikh s videodispleinymi terminalami.</title> <excerpt>The investigations have shown that military and aviation specialist working with video-display terminals are exposed to unfavourable effect of professional environment of anthropogenic genesis. It is accompanied with development of energo-informative stress. Manifestations of stress-effect have a cumulative character.</excerpt>

title: An empirical assessment of situation awareness in an instrument flight rules (IFR) aviation simulation
doc: <title>An empirical assessment of situation awareness in an instrument flight rules (IFR) aviation simulation</title> <excerpt>Situation awareness (SA) has received much attention from researchers during the past decade. However, many empirical attempts to examine SA are flawed because they rely solely on measures of performance to indicate the presence or absence of SA. This research assumed that SA was a descriptive label for correspondence, a phenomenon that could be defined operationally and examined empirically to determine its relationship to performance.</excerpt>

title: Leadership and job satisfaction among aviation fire fighters in Australia
doc: <title>Leadership and job satisfaction among aviation fire fighters in Australia</title> <excerpt>Recently important changes have been made to fire service management practices in Australia; however, these changes have typically not been based on empirical research or followed up by systematic evaluation. While job satisfaction and leadership behavior have been extensively investigated in other fields, studies of these variables in the fire service, particularly in Australia, are almost absent. This article examines links between job satisfaction and leadership behavior in aviation fire fighters.</excerpt>

title: A closed-loop system for examining psychophysiological measures for adaptive task allocation
doc: <title>A closed-loop system for examining psychophysiological measures for adaptive task allocation</title> <excerpt>A closed-loop system was evaluated for its efficacy in using psychophysiological indexes to moderate workload. Participants were asked to perform either 1 or 3 tasks from the Multiattribute Task Battery and complete the NASA Task Load Index after each trial. An electroencephalogram (EEG) was sampled continuously while they performed the tasks, and an EEG index (beta/alpha plus theta) was derived.</excerpt>

title: Sharing the burden of flight deck automation training
doc: <title>Sharing the burden of flight deck automation training</title> <excerpt>Flight deck automation has generated new training requirements, most of which have been absorbed by in-house airline training, in particular, aircraft transition training. This leaves little room for learning about how human roles have shifted in automated cockpits or how the distinction between technical and nontechnical skills has become blurred when managing the flight path of an automated aircraft. This article explores how overall pilot training quality, efficiency, and effectiveness would benefit from pulling automation training forward into the pilot training curriculum, reducing the burden carried mainly by transition training today.</excerpt>

title: A psychometric approach to the development of a multidimensional scale to assess aircraft handling qualities
doc: <title>A psychometric approach to the development of a multidimensional scale to assess aircraft handling qualities</title> <excerpt>This article describes the development of a multidimensional scale for the assessment of aircraft handling qualities using psychometric principles. A sample of 141 test pilots completed a structured assessment of their aircraft's handling qualities in 7 common flight maneuvers. From a series of confirmatory factor analyses, 5 stable dimensions of aircraft handling qualities were elicited.</excerpt>

title: Facilitating LOFT debriefings: Instructor techniques and crew participation
doc: <title>Facilitating LOFT debriefings: Instructor techniques and crew participation</title> <excerpt>This study analyzes techniques instructor pilots (IPs) use to facilitate crew analysis and evaluation of line-oriented flight training performance. We analyzed IP facilitation and crew participation for 36 debriefing sessions conducted at 5 U.S. airlines.</excerpt>

title: The prediction of judgment in realistic tasks: An investigation of self-insight
doc: <title>The prediction of judgment in realistic tasks: An investigation of self-insight</title> <excerpt>Two approaches to policy-capturing research - mathematical and verbal - were compared to determine if flight instructors, psychology professors, and college football coaches evaluating "paper students" in profile booklets had self-insight into their judgment policies. Contrary to a widely accepted view that people lack self-insight, results suggested that many of the judges, particularly among the flight instructors, demonstrated self-insight; fewer professors and coaches showed self-insight as defined for this study. Possible biasing factors in the study, implications for training, and probable reasons for the findings are given..</excerpt>

title: The shape of aviation psychology: A review of articles published in the first 5 years of The International Journal of Aviation Psychology
doc: <title>The shape of aviation psychology: A review of articles published in the first 5 years of The International Journal of Aviation Psychology</title> <excerpt>The International Journal of Aviation Psychology became the first journal devoted solely to aviation psychology with the appearance of its first issue in 1991. In the first 5 years (1991-1995 inclusive), 20 issues containing 104 articles have been published. This study was designed to illuminate the nature of aviation psychology by an examination of the material published in its flagship journal.</excerpt>

title: Display effects on shaping apparent strategy: A case study in collision detection and avoidance
doc: <title>Display effects on shaping apparent strategy: A case study in collision detection and avoidance</title> <excerpt>This article examines participants' behavior at collision detection and avoidance during parallel approaches and tests how it is affected by additional information on traffic displays. Participant behavior is analyzed by looking for "apparent strategies," measured by characteristics of participants' actions that remain consistent across scenar-ios with strongly different dynamics. The participants' collision detection reactions are found to occur at aircraft lateral separations that are consistent across a variety of scenarios; likewise, collision avoidance maneuvers with a "turn-away" component are consistently chosen for all scenarios.</excerpt>

title: Culture at Work in Aviation and Medicine: National, Organizational, and Professional Influences
doc: <title>Culture at Work in Aviation and Medicine: National, Organizational, and Professional Influences</title> <excerpt>Culture at Work in Aviation and Medicine: National Organizational and Professional Influences, by Robert L. Helmreich and Ashleigh C. Merritt, is reviewed..</excerpt>

title: Automation management strategies: Pilot preferences and operational experiences
doc: <title>Automation management strategies: Pilot preferences and operational experiences</title> <excerpt>With the evolution of technology from passive tool to highly independent agent, it is becoming increasingly important to support operators in coordinating human and machine intentions and actions. One way to achieve this goal is the context-sensitive use and implementation of different automation management strategies. This study examined pilots' preferences for and their operational experiences with 3 different strategies - management-by-consent, management-by-exception, and full automation.</excerpt>

title: The effect of pilot age on perceptions of pilot performance and attitudes toward the implementation of ergonomic redesign interventions for older pilots
doc: <title>The effect of pilot age on perceptions of pilot performance and attitudes toward the implementation of ergonomic redesign interventions for older pilots</title> <excerpt>As the workforce increasingly ages, it will be critical to find ways of accommodating the decrements in abilities that come with age. Finding accommodations will be of particular concern for occupations such as airline pilot, in which small errors may result in fatal accidents. This study examined the perceived performance of older pilots, if information on ergonomic redesign interventions had a significant effect on attitudes toward ergonomic redesign interventions for older pilots, and how perceived performance and type of information interacted to affect attitudes toward ergonomic redesign interventions for older pilots.</excerpt>

title: Automation bias and errors: Are crews better than individuals?
doc: <title>Automation bias and errors: Are crews better than individuals?</title> <excerpt>The availability of automated decision aids can sometimes feed into the general human tendency to travel the road of least cognitive effort. Is this tendency toward "automation bias" (the use of automation as a heuristic replacement for vigilant information seeking and processing) ameliorated when more than one decision maker is monitoring system events? This study examined automation bias in two-person crews versus solo performers under varying instruction conditions. Training that focused on automation bias and associated errors successfully reduced commission, but not omission, errors.</excerpt>

title: The effects of pictorial detail on the timing of the landing flare: Results of a visual simulation experiment
doc: <title>The effects of pictorial detail on the timing of the landing flare: Results of a visual simulation experiment</title> <excerpt>Artificial outside-world displays currently used in flight simulators may, in the future, also be applied to aircraft cockpits to enhance vision or to provide a completely synthetic replacement. In both cases, a very important question for designers of such displays is which elements of pictorial detail in the presented image are needed for satisfactory task or mission performance. Two elements of pictorial detail, a visible runway outline and ground texture, are considered in this article.</excerpt>

title: Error types and related error detection mechanisms in the aviation domain: An analysis of aviation safety reporting system incident reports
doc: <title>Error types and related error detection mechanisms in the aviation domain: An analysis of aviation safety reporting system incident reports</title> <excerpt>Human error is considered a contributing factor in 70% to 80% of all aviation accidents. Because errors can never be eliminated completely, a further reduction of the already low accident rate in this domain will require investments in better support for error management. In particular, a better understanding of the nature and effectiveness of error detection mechanisms is needed.</excerpt>

title: An analysis of slant for guidance of landing approaches
doc: <title>An analysis of slant for guidance of landing approaches</title> <excerpt>For landing without visual aids, judgment of slant angle from texture gradients may be the primary strategy used by pilots to maintain a constant angle of descent toward a runway aimpoint. A mathematical analysis was undertaken to assess whether 1 or more of the available texture gradients have the properties required to support this strategy. The analysis revealed that texture gradients in themselves could not be useful.</excerpt>

title: Accuracy of estimations made by air traffic controllers
doc: <title>Accuracy of estimations made by air traffic controllers</title> <excerpt>This study focuses on the accuracy of estimates made by air traffic controllers of aircraft future positions. The aim is to gain deeper understanding of anticipatory activity in dynamic situations. Analysis of the results reveals response biases of which the most common is that controllers predict aircraft positions as being closer than their actual positions.</excerpt>

title: Traumatic stress and death anxiety among community residents exposed to an aircraft crash
doc: <title>Traumatic stress and death anxiety among community residents exposed to an aircraft crash</title> <excerpt>This article examined the relationship between traumatic stress and death anxiety among community residents who lived near woodlands in which an aircraft had crashed in Coventry, England. The hypothesis was that there would be a high level of impact of the crash experienced by residents and that the residents would experience psychological distress..</excerpt>

title: Civil aircraft warning systems: Future directions in information management and presentation
doc: <title>Civil aircraft warning systems: Future directions in information management and presentation</title> <excerpt>Aviation statistics often cite human error and, in particular, crew decision making as a primary cause in explanations of aircraft accidents and incidents. Part of the solution to managing error may lie in the development of human-centered flight deck warning systems, which not only are error tolerant but also actively aid crew decision making. This article describes some of the findings from a comprehensive questionnaire survey of civil flight deck crew carried out to locate user requirements for the next generation of warning systems.</excerpt>

title: Helmet-mounted display symbology for terrain avoidance during low-level maneuvers
doc: <title>Helmet-mounted display symbology for terrain avoidance during low-level maneuvers</title> <excerpt>A simulation study was performed to evaluate helmet-mounted display symbology for fighter aircraft ground collision avoidance systems. Four visual alert symbologies were tested: an iconic cue, an aircraft-fixed (AF) guidance cue, a head-fixed (HF) guidance cue, and an HF guidance cue with a pitch ladder. Participants were given audio and visual side tasks and responded to alerts in different aircraft attitudes.</excerpt>

title: The need for multisensory interfaces in support of effective attention allocation in highly dynamic event-driven domains: The case of cockpit automation
doc: <title>The need for multisensory interfaces in support of effective attention allocation in highly dynamic event-driven domains: The case of cockpit automation</title> <excerpt>In a variety of domains, automation technology has evolved from passive tools to highly autonomous agents that can initiate actions independent of user input and without explicit operator consent. This evolution brings with it an increased need for effective human-automation communication and coordination to ensure that both agents stay informed about each others' goals, activities, and limitations. Yet, most modern systems are not equipped with the skills required to contribute effectively and in a timely manner to the exchange of information on commitments and actions.</excerpt>

title: Organisational failure: Lessons from industry applied in the medical domain
doc: <title>Organisational failure: Lessons from industry applied in the medical domain</title> <excerpt>Risk management in the medical domain and medical accidents in particular are receiving growing interest from researchers in industrial engineering and management sciences, psychology, and human factors. Historically there has been little systematic attempt to explore and assess safety for both staff and patients in the medical domain. Conversely, many methods exist to analyse safety and risks in industrial settings, particularly in high-risk industries such as chemical processing, the nuclear power industry, and aviation.</excerpt>

title: Neuroendocrine responses to psychological workload of instrument flying in student pilots
doc: <title>Neuroendocrine responses to psychological workload of instrument flying in student pilots</title> <excerpt>Background: Information processing and stress tolerance are necessary features for instrument flying (IRF), especially among student pilots. Psychological workload of IFR flight may lead to stress reactions such as neuroendocrine activity. Methods: Neuroendocrine responses to an IFR flight with Vinka piston-engined primary trainer were studied in 35 male volunteers who participated in the basic military flying course of the Finnish Air Force (FAF).</excerpt>

title: "Blanche et Noir": Louise Faure-Favier and the liberated woman.
doc: <title>"Blanche et Noir": Louise Faure-Favier and the liberated woman.</title>

title: Niche Channels : A Study on Status and Trends in India
doc: <title>Niche Channels : A Study on Status and Trends in India</title> <excerpt>The purpose of this study is to study the trends of viewership of niche channels in India. The scope of the study is restricted to Music Channels, Information Channels(Discovery) and News Channels(Star News).Secondary research was carried out by studying the trends of ratings and channel share of these channels from INTAM across of two periods of Jan'98- Mar'98 and Nov'98-Jan'99. The target audience was SEC A & B, 15-24 years and 25-34 years.Primary research was conducted among 10 media planners, 40 households and two channel marketers.The analysis of ratings showed that the ratings for these channels peaked during prime-time which in India is the time when TV viewing is the highest.</excerpt>

title: Victim identification and family support in mass casualties: the Massachusetts model.
doc: <title>Victim identification and family support in mass casualties: the Massachusetts model.</title> <excerpt>The Aviation Disaster Family Assistance Act of 1996 requires the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB), air carriers, and the American Red Cross (ARC) to provide an integrated family assistance center to offer support to family survivors of mass casualties. A central component of post-incident response is the timely identification of victims and their personal belongings. This identification process occurs through antemortem interviews with family survivors.</excerpt>

title: Ways to improve prophylactic work in aviation medicine; Puti sovershenstvovaniia profilakticheskoi raboty v aviatsionnoi meditsine.
doc: <title>Ways to improve prophylactic work in aviation medicine; Puti sovershenstvovaniia profilakticheskoi raboty v aviatsionnoi meditsine.</title>

title: Aerospace clinical psychology and its role in serving practitioners of hazardous activities.
doc: <title>Aerospace clinical psychology and its role in serving practitioners of hazardous activities.</title> <excerpt>Aerospace clinical psychology is defined as a special application of psychology to the hazardous and stressful occupations associated with aviation and space flight. Aerospace clinical psychological services usually are offered on a unit or organizational level, though interventions can be designed for individuals and their families. The application of aerospace clinical psychology to the "failing aviator" is described and the current status of the field is provided.</excerpt>

title: Prevalence and predictors of discharge in United States Air Force Basic Military Training
doc: <title>Prevalence and predictors of discharge in United States Air Force Basic Military Training</title> <excerpt>The purpose of the current investigation was to determine the prospective predictors of discharge in a population of individuals entering U.S. Air Force Basic Military Training (BMT). Subjects were 32,144 consecutive individuals entering Air Force BMT.</excerpt>

title: The evolution of crew resource management training in commercial aviation
doc: <title>The evolution of crew resource management training in commercial aviation</title> <excerpt>In this study, we describe changes in the nature of Crew Resource Management (CRM) training in commercial aviation, including its shift from cockpit to crew resource management. Validation of the impact of CRM is discussed. Limitations of CRM, including lack of cross-cultural generality are considered.</excerpt>

title: The effect of moderate levels of simulated altitude on sustained cognitive performance
doc: <title>The effect of moderate levels of simulated altitude on sustained cognitive performance</title> <excerpt>Previous work has documented cognitive deficits at high altitudes (15,000-25,000 ft), but there is controversy for lower altitudes. This study looked at the effects of moderate altitudes - 12,500 ft and 15,000 ft - on short-term memory in comparison to 2,000 ft. Seventy-two student pilots and instructors were first administered the Vocabulary, Digit Span, and Digit Symbol subtests from the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale-Revised, the Vandenberg Mental Rotation Test, and the near-contrast sensitivity portion of the Vistech VCTS 6000 chart.</excerpt>

title: The effect of experience on the perception of decision scenarios: A field study
doc: <title>The effect of experience on the perception of decision scenarios: A field study</title> <excerpt>Multidimensional Scaling (MDS) was used to examine differences in the perceptions of individuals at different levels of experience in the same profession. Using a procedure similar to that described by Fischer, Orasanu, and Wich (1995), aviators, representing four levels of experience, sorted 27 descriptions of aviation scenarios into categories of similar problem type. Each participant also rated the scenarios on a series of bipolar scales.</excerpt>

title: FACE: Fear of loss of face and the five hazardous attitudes concept
doc: <title>FACE: Fear of loss of face and the five hazardous attitudes concept</title> <excerpt>An aspect of human personality, fear of loss of face, has attracted only minimal experimental investigation, despite the widespread recognition of the condition and its potentially adverse effects on behavior. A survey of the available literature shows fear of loss of face to be an important aspect of pilot decision making. This article considers the phenomenon in more detail and recommends an amendment to the 5 hazardous attitudes concept developed at the Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University (Diehl, 1990).</excerpt>

title: Functional interface design for the modern aircraft cockpit
doc: <title>Functional interface design for the modern aircraft cockpit</title> <excerpt>There is an emerging concern that modern glass cockpits induce information overload. This is sometimes thought to be an inevitable result of the increased complexity and the need for automation that accompanies the transition to high technology. We argue here that the human performance problems created by glass cockpits are not an inevitable consequence of increased hardware complexity or of automation but, instead, are a result of nonfunctional design that increases complexity at the cockpit interface.</excerpt>

title: Modes in human-machine systems: Constructs, representation, and classification
doc: <title>Modes in human-machine systems: Constructs, representation, and classification</title> <excerpt>This article surveys and discusses human interaction with automated control systems that employ modes. We focus our discussion on the features of the control system that lead to mode confusion and error. We first provide working definitions of the term mode and discuss key constructs that contribute to mode error, such as mode ambiguity and user expectations.</excerpt>

title: The effect of level of automation on time spent looking out of the cockpit
doc: <title>The effect of level of automation on time spent looking out of the cockpit</title> <excerpt>This study examines the effect of level of automation in the cockpit on the proportion of time commercial airline pilots looked out of the cockpit during takeoffs and landings. Data were obtained from 1 model of the B737-200 and 2 models of the B737-300. The B737-200 had an advanced autopilot and traditional instruments.</excerpt>

title: The development of specifications for an automated monitoring system interface associated with aircraft condition
doc: <title>The development of specifications for an automated monitoring system interface associated with aircraft condition</title> <excerpt>Because of the complexity and interconnectedness of aircraft subsystems, considerable interpretation is required to determine the implications of conventional system warnings and to decide on the appropriate course of action to ameliorate a fault condition. This article focuses on the case of mechanical fault conditions in rotorcraft. Until recently, only a few simple sensors (eg, oil pressure and temperature, oil debris sensor) were provided to signal mechanical faults.</excerpt>

title: Automation in general aviation: Two studies of pilot responses to autopilot malfunctions
doc: <title>Automation in general aviation: Two studies of pilot responses to autopilot malfunctions</title> <excerpt>Study 1 examined 4 automation-related malfunctions (runaway pitch trim up, roll servo failure, roll sensor failure, pitch drift up) and subsequent pilot responses. Study 2 examined 4 additional malfunctions, 2 more immediately obvious (runaway pitch trim down, runaway roll servo) and 2 more subtle (failed attitude indicator, pitch sensor drift down) than those in Study 1, and the effect of an auditory warning. Data collection was performed in the Civil Aeromedical Institute's Advanced General Aviation Research Simulator, configured as a Piper Malibu.</excerpt>

title: Shared models of flight management system vertical guidance
doc: <title>Shared models of flight management system vertical guidance</title> <excerpt>Solutions to operational and training issues with flight automation should be based on a complete model of the behaviors of the avionics software shared by pilots, developers, trainers, and human factors researchers. The operational procedure model, described in this article, represents the behavior of the avionics software as a set of intentions associated with situation-action rules. This article focuses on the guidance function incorporated in flight management systems and presents an operational procedure model of vertical guidance..</excerpt>

title: Work domain analysis for training-system definition and acquisition
doc: <title>Work domain analysis for training-system definition and acquisition</title> <excerpt>Training-needs analysis is critical for defining and procuring effective training systems. However, traditional approaches to training-needs analysis are not suitable for capturing the demands of highly automated and computerized work domains. In this article, we propose that work domain analysis can identify the functional structure of a work domain that must be captured in a training system, so that workers can be trained to deal with unpredictable contingencies that cannot be handled by computer systems.</excerpt>

title: Relationship between learning preferences of Federal Aviation Administration flight inspection operations personnel and outcome scores on Crew Resource Management Training Course
doc: <title>Relationship between learning preferences of Federal Aviation Administration flight inspection operations personnel and outcome scores on Crew Resource Management Training Course</title> <excerpt>Scope and method of study. The purpose of this study was to examine relationships between learning preferences of students attending Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) Flight Inspection Crew Resource Management (CRM) Phase I Awareness Training and their outcome scores on the end of course final exam. Participants in this study were 135 flight operations personnel of the FAA Aviation System Standards organization who attended a newly established CRM Phase I training program.</excerpt>

title: Conceptual design guidelines to rediscover systems engineering for automated flight decks
doc: <title>Conceptual design guidelines to rediscover systems engineering for automated flight decks</title> <excerpt>An analysis of more than 50 accidents involving automated commercial transport aircraft showed that most of them attributed to pilot error involved reprogramming of automated systems. An examination of current aircraft automation and automation-related training and operations strongly suggests that a major factor in this situation is the lack of adequate systems engineering in the automation development process. An examination of contemporary commercial aircraft systems under guidelines developed in the systems engineering process for an early military terrain-following system reveals weaknesses in the design of the commercial systems.</excerpt>

title: US scientific community joins forces to support research
doc: <title>US scientific community joins forces to support research</title> <excerpt>The American Institute of Biological Sciences (AIBS) has joined other scientific and business organizations in sending letters to Congress, urging much-needed funding increases for federal research programs. The Science, Engineering and Technology Working Group organized the letter-writing campaign..</excerpt>

title: Designing functional visualizations for aircraft systems status displays
doc: <title>Designing functional visualizations for aircraft systems status displays</title> <excerpt>A number of researchers have observed that glass cockpit displays tend to be opaque and that this makes it difficult for the flight crew to develop accurate and comprehensive mental models of system functioning, thereby leading to errors in abnormal situations. However, few researchers have suggested how to create better functional visualizations of system behavior, and even fewer have provided examples of what such advanced displays might look like. This article describes how the principles of ecological interface design (EID), a framework developed in the context of process control, can be applied in aviation to design engineering systems status displays.</excerpt>

title: The use of autonomic components to improve cardiovascular assessment of mental workload in flight simulation
doc: <title>The use of autonomic components to improve cardiovascular assessment of mental workload in flight simulation</title> <excerpt>Principal components analysis of multiple psychophysiological measures of cardiovascular activity was used to derive the underlying sympathetic and parasympathetic information needed to represent the autonomic space for heart period. This method was applied to cardiac data that were previously collected during a full-mission flight simulation from volunteer commercial pilots (Corwin et al, 1989). Pilots flew both low-and high-workload mission scenarios in 2 separate test sessions.</excerpt>

title: Impact of silence: A discourse analysis of black box miscommunications of three fatal flights
doc: <title>Impact of silence: A discourse analysis of black box miscommunications of three fatal flights</title> <excerpt>In a unique research attempt to identify the interpersonal and communication process dynamics of three fatal crews, data obtained from long-guarded “black box” recordings of critical last minutes of flight were analyzed. Although most “black boxes” have been protected vehemently by airline professionals, and used exclusively for National Transportation and Safety Board's investigations, a dearth of research involving “crew errors” prior to actual accidents prompted a several industry experts to entrust portions of tapes from two accidents to the present investigator for this study. Supplemental information from a third aviation accident report also was used.</excerpt>

title: Who's balancing the federal research portfolio and how?
doc: <title>Who's balancing the federal research portfolio and how?</title> <excerpt>Merrill and McGeary examine the allocation of public research support by the government. Psychology and biological aspects of research will be showing the most changes in federal research obligations..</excerpt>

title: Transfer of training effectiveness of a personal computer aviation training device
doc: <title>Transfer of training effectiveness of a personal computer aviation training device</title> <excerpt>The training effectiveness of personal computer aviation training devices (PCATDs) has received only limited testing. In the experiment reported here, a commercially available PCATD was evaluated for its transfer effectiveness for teaching of instrument flight skills. Students from the beginning and advanced instrument courses at the University of Illinois were trained to criterion in the PCATD on a wide range of tasks and were then retrained to criterion in the airplane on the same tasks.</excerpt>

title: Attitudes toward unsafe acts in a sample of Australian general aviation pilots
doc: <title>Attitudes toward unsafe acts in a sample of Australian general aviation pilots</title> <excerpt>The aim of this research was the development and validation of a questionnaire designed to examine attitudes toward unsafe acts that mitigate involvement in human error-related accidents and incidents. A 25-item questionnaire was designed and completed by a sample of 70 pilots in the Australian general aviation industry. The data analysis involved considerations of internal reliability and concurrent validity, in addition to comparisons between experience levels and attendance at human factors seminars.</excerpt>

title: Development and evaluation of a background attitude indicator
doc: <title>Development and evaluation of a background attitude indicator</title> <excerpt>In this article, we describe a series of 3 studies conducted to evaluate the feasibility of using a unique type of attitude indicator, called a background attitude indicator (BAI), to recover from unusual attitudes. The BAI is a head-down display format that combines tactical information in the central portion of the display with attitude information in the border surrounding the tactical information. The attitude information, in essence, frames the tactics display.</excerpt>

title: The incidence of incidents: A nationwide study of flight experience and exposure to accidents and incidents
doc: <title>The incidence of incidents: A nationwide study of flight experience and exposure to accidents and incidents</title>

title: Safety prejudices, training practices, and CRM: A midpoint perspective
doc: <title>Safety prejudices, training practices, and CRM: A midpoint perspective</title> <excerpt>Problems in the application of data from accidents and incidents in the design of crew training are discussed. An alternative approach, monitoring normal operations, is proposed and described. Criticisms of the usefulness of crew resource management (CRM) training based on accidents are considered, and the importance of normal process monitoring for evaluation of CRM efficacy is discussed..</excerpt>

title: Datalink communication in flight deck operations: A synthesis of recent studies
doc: <title>Datalink communication in flight deck operations: A synthesis of recent studies</title> <excerpt>Current datalink technology provides alphanumeric messages to aircrews using an air-ground digital link. This system produces a procedural change by modifying the way pilots and air traffic controllers interact. During the last 10 years, many studies have sought to understand and improve pilots' activities and the relationships among controllers and pilots.</excerpt>

title: Describing traumatic responses and distress of community residents directly and indirectly exposed to an aircraft crash
doc: <title>Describing traumatic responses and distress of community residents directly and indirectly exposed to an aircraft crash</title> <excerpt>This study described the traumatic responses and the extent of psychological distress among residents who had been exposed directly or indirectly to an aircraft crash in Coventry, U.K. The direct exposure group consisted of 62 residents who were on the housing estate at the time of the accident and 20 who were not. They were interviewed on their subjective responses to the crash and then asked to fill in two distress measures: the Impact of Event Scale (IES) and the General Health Questionnaire (GHQ).</excerpt>

title: A longitudinal field investigation of antecedents and consequences of self-efficacy during aviation training
doc: <title>A longitudinal field investigation of antecedents and consequences of self-efficacy during aviation training</title> <excerpt>A key variable in many models of self-regulation has been self-efficacy, a person's belief that he or she can execute a task at a certain level of performance. This study examined the development of self-efficacy and the extent to which self-efficacy affected subsequent performance in an aviation training setting. Furthermore, this study extends previous investigations and contributes to the self-efficacy literature by examining how perceptions of training instrumentality affect the development of self-efficacy.</excerpt>

title: Commonalities, conflicts and contradictions in organizational masculinities; exploring the gendered genesis of the Challenger disaster
doc: <title>Commonalities, conflicts and contradictions in organizational masculinities; exploring the gendered genesis of the Challenger disaster</title> <excerpt>The events surrounding the 1986 decision to launch the Space Shuttle Challenger are reconstructed to illustrate how multiple masculinities, particularly between and among managers and engineers, contributed to that organizational crisis. An analysis of gendered power relations--especially among men--reveals how the construction of particular forms of "masculinities," and the ways in which they are reproduced, rationalized or resisted, vary as a result of contextual changes. Commonalities and differences among these masculinities are discussed.</excerpt>

title: Reserve resources model: Increasing problem -solving capacity through controlled processing
doc: <title>Reserve resources model: Increasing problem -solving capacity through controlled processing</title> <excerpt>In this paper a new central capacity model of human performance called the Reserve Resources Model is developed. This model makes specific predictions related to human interactions with machines in complex systems and provides a useful framework for designers to follow when determining future task allocations. This theory predicts that operators of systems requiring decision-making should be assigned tasks requiring controlled processing.</excerpt>

title: Computer-based simulation as an adjunct to Ab initio flight training
doc: <title>Computer-based simulation as an adjunct to Ab initio flight training</title> <excerpt>Two groups of ab initio student pilots were given training on a flight simulation package running on a desk-top computer prior to performing some basic flight maneuvers in the air. One group interacted with the computer using a representative set of flight controls. The other group used only the computer's cursor and function keys.</excerpt>

title: Status and cockpit dynamics: A review and empirical study
doc: <title>Status and cockpit dynamics: A review and empirical study</title> <excerpt>One of the most troublesome dynamics evident in the airplane cockpit is related to patterns of authority relations between the captain and the first officer: Too often, captains fail to listen and first officers fail to speak. The authors propose that many instances of superordinate and subordinate behavior in the cockpit-the captain's tendency to reject input from other team members and the first officer's hesitancy to question the captain-represent cases of status generalization. First, the authors describe the theory of status generalization and show support for the operation of the theory by presenting examples of flightcrew behavior that the theory predicts.</excerpt>

title: From present day aviation medicine to aviation anthropologic ecology of the future; Ot aviatsionnoi meditsiny nastoiashchego k aviatsionnoi antropoekologii budushchego.
doc: <title>From present day aviation medicine to aviation anthropologic ecology of the future; Ot aviatsionnoi meditsiny nastoiashchego k aviatsionnoi antropoekologii budushchego.</title> <excerpt>Rationale is given to the proposition that aviation medicine including psychophysiology and ergonomics is a peculiar kind of aviation anthropoecology as a variety of the present-day integrative science of human. This is grounded, firstly, on analysis of any scientific finding of aviation medicine in the light of two principles of the contemporary occupational medicine, ie human health and reasonable risk (which is an equivalent of safety) and, secondly, systemic study from this angle of all, from molecular to social, levels of the biological integration man of flying..</excerpt>

title: Crew resource management for offshore teams: Lessons from aviation.
doc: <title>Crew resource management for offshore teams: Lessons from aviation.</title> <excerpt>The European and North American airlines now use a specialized form of human factors training for pilots, ground and cabin crew, called Crew Resource Management (CRM). It is mandatory in the UK that all airline pilots undertake CRM training. CRM emerged as a result of accident analysis (eg Tenerife air disaster) which showed that human factors relating to leadership, problem solving, communication, team working and stress management were contributing to near misses and accidents.</excerpt>

title: The attributes of medical event-reporting systems: Experience with a prototype medical event-reporting system for transfusion medicine
doc: <title>The attributes of medical event-reporting systems: Experience with a prototype medical event-reporting system for transfusion medicine</title> <excerpt>Objective. - To design, develop, and implement a prototype medical event-reporting system for use in transfusion medicine to improve transfusion safety by studying incidents and errors. Methods.</excerpt>

title: Different effects of physical exercise on cold pain sensitivity in fighter pilots with and without the history of acute in-flight neck pain attacks
doc: <title>Different effects of physical exercise on cold pain sensitivity in fighter pilots with and without the history of acute in-flight neck pain attacks</title> <excerpt>Purpose: The cold pain sensitivity in fighter pilots was studied by using a cold pressor test. Methods: The pilots were divided into two groups: one group consisting of eight pilots (N = 8) who had experienced several acute in-flight neck pain attacks, and the control group (N = 8) who had not experienced these pain conditions under similar work and environment conditions. In each pilot cold pain thresholds and pain and unpleasantness responses to suprathreshold cold stimulations were recorded during repeated tests.</excerpt>

title: Characteristics of nystagmus and illusion evoked by optokinetic stimuli
doc: <title>Characteristics of nystagmus and illusion evoked by optokinetic stimuli</title> <excerpt>To study the characteristics of human psychophysiological responses to optokinetic stimulus, 30 male medical students were given a series of optokinetic step stimulus (5, 10, 15, 20, 30, 40, 60, 80, 100, 120 deg/sec) (clockwise). Each stimulus lasted for 20 seconds. Optokinetic nystagmus was recorded on tape.</excerpt>

title: Changes in the performance of a synthetic work task as a function of age, gender, and sleep deprivation
doc: <title>Changes in the performance of a synthetic work task as a function of age, gender, and sleep deprivation</title> <excerpt>A 4-hour sleep-loss study was conducted as part of a larger Department of Transportation-Federal Aviation Administration (DOT/FAA) fatigue research program to assess the ability of traditional and innovative measures to track drowsiness and fatigue. Twenty-seven subjects were grouped by age and gender, and randomly paired for weekend testing. Performance testing using a synthetic work task was completed 4, 10, 16, 22, 28, and 34 hr after waking at 6 am.</excerpt>

title: Gender influences on performance, mood and recovery sleep in fatigued aviators
doc: <title>Gender influences on performance, mood and recovery sleep in fatigued aviators</title> <excerpt>Female aviators now are able to serve in combat roles, but few studies have addressed potential differences between the ability of males and females to withstand combat stressors. This study examined responses of men and women to one operational stressor, sleep deprivation. Pilots were tested on flight performance and mood during 40-h periods of sustained wakefulness.</excerpt>

title: Programmable personality interface for the dynamic infrared scene generator (IRSG2)
doc: <title>Programmable personality interface for the dynamic infrared scene generator (IRSG2)</title> <excerpt>As scene generator platforms begin to rely specifically on commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) hardware and software components, the need for high speed programmable personality interfaces (PPIs) are required for interfacing to Infrared (IR) flight computer/processors and complex IR projectors in the hardware-in-the-loop (HWIL) simulation facilities. Recent technological advances and innovative applications of established technologies are beginning to allow development of cost effective PPIs to interface to COTS scene generators. At the U.S.</excerpt>

title: Temporal management of flight strips in en route air traffic control: A full-scope simulation test on task analyses assumptions
doc: <title>Temporal management of flight strips in en route air traffic control: A full-scope simulation test on task analyses assumptions</title> <excerpt>In en route air traffic control, task analyses assume that the planning controller detects potential problems to alleviate the radar controller's workload. Ten expert controllers were involved in a full-scope simulation study, and displacements of flight strips were analyzed as a function of the controller and as a function of the role these motor acts have in indicating problem detection, monitoring the ongoing resolution, or sending the aircraft to other control positions. Task analysis assumptions related to the ongoing resolution and to the end of problems were confirmed.</excerpt>

title: An experimental comparison of alphanumeric and iconic formats of the Flight Mode annunciator
doc: <title>An experimental comparison of alphanumeric and iconic formats of the Flight Mode annunciator</title> <excerpt>An iconic alternative was designed for the conventional alphanumeric Flight Mode Annunciator (FMA) display. The two FMA types were compared in three experiments. In the first experiment, participants had to recall an FMA display that was presented for a short period of time.</excerpt>

title: Evidence for the validity of PC-based simulations in studying aircrew coordination
doc: <title>Evidence for the validity of PC-based simulations in studying aircrew coordination</title> <excerpt>Recently, advances in computer technology have allowed the use of PC-based simulations for a variety of aviation training and research purposes. One area in particular where PC-based simulations have been used extensively is the study of aircrew coordination. Yet, there have always been lingering questions about the validity of these simulations.</excerpt>

title: Evaluating the effectiveness of flight simulators for training combat skills: A review
doc: <title>Evaluating the effectiveness of flight simulators for training combat skills: A review</title> <excerpt>The military is focusing a great deal of effort on developing virtual world technologies that will allow training combat skills in flight simulators. Considerably less attention is being directed toward documenting the effectiveness of such training. In this article, we review Air Force and Navy efforts to evaluate the effectiveness of training the combat skills necessary for attack and fighter aircraft in flight simulators.</excerpt>

title: Australian aviation safety - Observations from the 'lucky' country
doc: <title>Australian aviation safety - Observations from the 'lucky' country</title> <excerpt>This paper examines the reasons behind Australia's good record for commercial jet aircraft operations. The results indicate a complex system of factors ranging from the anecdotal theories on weather, terrain, traffic density and luck together with deeper human factors issues such as the influence of culture at national, industry and organisational levels and the influence of key historical events and personalities. This paper illustrates how these inputs have interacted with each other and the effect this has on the level of risk acceptability within Australian aviation.</excerpt>

title: Predicting naval aviator flight training performance using multiple regression and an artificial neural network
doc: <title>Predicting naval aviator flight training performance using multiple regression and an artificial neural network</title> <excerpt>The potential of a series of automated single-task and multitask tests to account for additional significant variance in the prediction of Navy pilot flight grades was evaluated. Volunteer participants (student naval aviators) were tested on a series of cognitive and perceptual psychomotor tests. The participants then entered the Navy's flight training program at Whiting Field, Florida.</excerpt>

title: Mixed-media communication on the flight deck: A comparison of voice, data link, and mixed ATC environments
doc: <title>Mixed-media communication on the flight deck: A comparison of voice, data link, and mixed ATC environments</title> <excerpt>A part-task simulation study compared pilots' responses to voice and data link air traffic control (ATC) messages in a single medium versus a mixed voice and data link ATC environment. Contrary to initial hypotheses, voice transaction times were longer in the mixed than in the single-medium environment, whereas data link transaction times were unaffected by the environment. The interval between ATC messages was also varied to examine the influence of time pressure in voice, data link, and mixed ATC environments.</excerpt>

title: A mathematical model of glide-slope perception in the visual approach to landing
doc: <title>A mathematical model of glide-slope perception in the visual approach to landing</title> <excerpt>A mathematical model of glide-slope perception is presented for the visual approach to landing when there is a visually impoverished scene. The perceptual process has been modeled as the weighted average of the geometric relations in the scene that provide glide-slope information, with weights being adjusted during the approach to minimize the uncertainty in glide-slope perception. The model suggests that the optimum combination of relations providing glide-slope information is dependent on the range from the runway threshold and that there is a relation between the handling qualities of aircraft or flight simulators and the adjustment of the weights..</excerpt>

title: Computer modeling of operator mental workload and situational awareness in simulated air-to-ground combat: An assessment of predictive validity
doc: <title>Computer modeling of operator mental workload and situational awareness in simulated air-to-ground combat: An assessment of predictive validity</title> <excerpt>The predictive validity of computer modeling of operator mental workload and situational awareness during a simulated air-to-ground combat mission was assessed. In Phase 1 of the study, 12 participants completed a series of simulated flights and provided Subjective Workload Assessment Technique (SWAT) ratings of workload and Situational Awareness Rating Technique (SART) ratings of situational awareness. In Phase 2, computer models of the combat mission were constructed using the Micro Saint modeling tool.</excerpt>

title: Elevation-dependent symptom, mood, and performance changes produced by exposure to hypobaric hypoxia
doc: <title>Elevation-dependent symptom, mood, and performance changes produced by exposure to hypobaric hypoxia</title> <excerpt>Altitude exposures above 3,000 m produce changes in symptoms, moods, and cognitive/motor performance of unacclimatized individuals and should produce graded effects on these parameters as elevation and duration are increased. This study examined effects on these parameters as a function of altitude level and duration of exposure by administering standardized tests from 1 to 3 times to 23 males in an altitude chamber during 4.5-hour exposures to 3 levels of hypobaric hypoxia: 500 m, 4,200 m, and 4,700 m. Exposure to altitude significantly affected symptoms, moods, and performance in an elevation-dependent fashion.</excerpt>

title: Head-up displays: Effects of clutter, display intensity, and display location on pilot performance
doc: <title>Head-up displays: Effects of clutter, display intensity, and display location on pilot performance</title> <excerpt>Two experiments examined the effects of display location (head-up and head-down), display clutter, and display intensity on pilot performance in a general aviation-cruise flight environment. In Experiment 1, a low-fidelity simulation revealed that the detection of commanded flight changes and flight-path tracking performance was better in the head-down condition as compared to the head-up condition. In contrast, midair traffic detection was superior with the head-up display (HUD), reflecting an attentional trade-off.</excerpt>

title: Oculographic assessment of workload influence on flight performance
doc: <title>Oculographic assessment of workload influence on flight performance</title> <excerpt>Presented are specific parameters of visual information intake in pilots on the job. The role of eye movements in the process of visual stimulus reception is discussed. Our own study on a MIG-23 flight simulator is presented.</excerpt>

title: It is not how much you have but how you use it: Toward a rational use of simulatio to support aviation training
doc: <title>It is not how much you have but how you use it: Toward a rational use of simulatio to support aviation training</title> <excerpt>One of the most remarkable changes in aviation training over the past few decades is the use of simulation. The capabilities now offered by simulation have created unlimited opportunities for aviation training. In fact, aviation training is now more realistic, safe, cost-effective, and flexible than ever before.</excerpt>

title: Pilot selection in the Norwegian Air Force: A validation and meta-analysis of the test battery
doc: <title>Pilot selection in the Norwegian Air Force: A validation and meta-analysis of the test battery</title> <excerpt>The purpose of this study was to evaluate the test battery currently used for pilot selection to the Norwegian Air Force. Selection is currently based on a standard battery of 20 different psychological tests as well as on medical tests and on an interview by a licensed psychologist.
