doc: <title>On risk factors causing neuroses and psychosomatic diseases in the flying personnel</title> <excerpt>On hundred and twnty one patients underwent psychological examinations using personality-opiented test (a standard method of personality examinations and a projective aviation test), 24 of which displayed neurotic states and 97 - psychosomatic diseases. Clinical and psychological examinations helped identify two basic patterns of psychic adaptation to stressful flying activities which manifested as asthenic trends and predisposition to nonconfromist behaviour. In the control group, that consisted of 165 graduates of a flying school, these patterns of psychic adaptation were rarely seen.</excerpt>

title: Specific features of aviation specialists with different psychological compatibility in small groups
doc: <title>Specific features of aviation specialists with different psychological compatibility in small groups</title> <excerpt>Professional interaction of members of small groups of aviation operators was subject to psychophysiological analysis. Using the study of professional interaction of operators and the theory of operational mediation of personality relations, the major parameters characterizing psychological compatibility were determined. The practical application of these characteristics helped select small groups of aviation specialists, who differed largely in their psychological compatibility, compare them in terms of a great number of personality parameters, and define their various combinations.</excerpt>

title: Community psychological effects following a non-fatal aircraft accident
doc: <title>Community psychological effects following a non-fatal aircraft accident</title> <excerpt>Following a non-fatal military aircraft accident, two of the authors interviewed the crewmen involved in the accident, their spouses, fellow squadron members and their spouses, and individuals from the fire crew and control tower on duty during the accident. A total of 37 respondents completed questionnaires which reported the presence of intrusive, avoidant, depressive/anxious, and post-traumatic stress symptoms. Spouses reported more symptoms after the accident than their flying husbands.</excerpt>

title: Human-Computer Interaction research at the University of Illinois
doc: <title>Human-Computer Interaction research at the University of Illinois</title> <excerpt>The Engineering Psychology program at the University of Illinois is interdisciplinary in nature and involves the participation of faculty members, undergraduate, graduate and post-doctoral students from the Department of Psychology, Department of Industrial Engineering, the Institute of Aviation, and the Beckman Institute. While the interests of the faculty members and the students run the gamut from nuts and bolts ergonomics to the design of intelligent systems there are two topics, the design of displays and the acquisition of perceptual-motor and cognitive skills, which serve as a unifying focus of research in Human-Computer Interaction. © 1990 ACM..</excerpt>

title: Psychiatric effects of military low-altitude flights on children; UBER DIE PSYCHISCHEN AUSWIRKUNGEN VON MILITARISCHER TIEFFLUGTATIGKEIT AUF KINDER
doc: <title>Psychiatric effects of military low-altitude flights on children; UBER DIE PSYCHISCHEN AUSWIRKUNGEN VON MILITARISCHER TIEFFLUGTATIGKEIT AUF KINDER</title> <excerpt>In a 2-step epidemiological study child psychiatric disorders, psychophysiological reactions and psychosocial stressors of 376 children aged 4 to 16 were recorded in two regions of Westphalia (West-Germany) with different frequencies of military low-level flights. No essential impairment of the children's health was found. However, below a clinical level we noticed significantly higher anxiety syndrome scores (and to some extent of depression syndrome scores) and a tendency towards higher psychophysiological arousal in the high-noice area along with no differences in psychosocial stressors.</excerpt>

title: Correlation Among Exact Word, Clozentropy and Pseudo-Clozentropy as Three Scoring Methods in Efl Cloze Tests
doc: <title>Correlation Among Exact Word, Clozentropy and Pseudo-Clozentropy as Three Scoring Methods in Efl Cloze Tests</title> <excerpt>Beş bölümden oluşan bu çalışmada 'cloze test' diye bilinen boşluk doldurma testi belirli bir bilgiyi ölçmek için değil sadece notlama metodları arasındaki ilişkiyi test etmek amacıyla kullanılmıştır. Çalışmanın amacı cloze testi notlamada kullanılan 'exact, word, 'clozentropy' ve bu çalışmada 'clozentropy' metodundan uyarlanan 'pseudo-clozentropy' arasında anlamlı bir ilişkinin var olup olmadığını saptamak, ayrıca bu üç metodla notlanan 'cloze test'in güvenirlik katsayısını hesaplayarak, en güvenilir, dolayısıyla en tercih edilebilir olanını saptamaktır.Birinci bölümde problemin kaynağı, problem, çalışmanın alanlı, sınırlılıkları ve tanımları yer almaktadır. İkinci bölümde çalışma ile ilgili kaynak taranmıştır.</excerpt>

title: The 'problem' with automation: inappropriate feedback and interaction, not 'over-automation'.
doc: <title>The 'problem' with automation: inappropriate feedback and interaction, not 'over-automation'.</title> <excerpt>As automation increasingly takes its place in industry, especially high risk industry, it is often blamed for causing harm and increasing the chance of human error when failures do occur. I propose that the problem is not the presence of automation, but rather its inappropriate design. The problem is that the operations under normal operating conditions are performed appropriately, but there is inadequate feedback and interaction with the humans who must control the overall conduct of the task.</excerpt>

title: Cross-cultural evaluation of the booklet version of the Category Test
doc: <title>Cross-cultural evaluation of the booklet version of the Category Test</title> <excerpt>The booklet version of the Category Test has demonstrated high validation with the original test. Seventy NATO pilots and 61 spouses were administered the booklet version of the Category Test. Ages of volunteers ranged from 18 to 51 and education level ranged from seven to 20 years.</excerpt>

title: The pharmacological correction with asparkam of the functional status of pilots in army aviation in a hot climate; Farmakologicheskaia korrektsiia asparkamom funktsional'nogo sostoianiia letchikov armeǐskoǐ aviatsii v usloviiakh zharkogo klimata.
doc: <title>The pharmacological correction with asparkam of the functional status of pilots in army aviation in a hot climate; Farmakologicheskaia korrektsiia asparkamom funktsional'nogo sostoianiia letchikov armeǐskoǐ aviatsii v usloviiakh zharkogo klimata.</title>

title: Corporate instability is related to airline pilots' stress symptoms
doc: <title>Corporate instability is related to airline pilots' stress symptoms</title> <excerpt>The Symptoms of Stress questionnaire was administered to three random samples of commercial airline pilots. Respondents included 1 group of 212 pilots who were employed by an airline company with a history of corporate instability; and 2 groups, totalling 220 pilots, who were employed by 2 airline carriers with histories of corporate stability. The pilot group employed by the airline with a history of corporate instability reported significantly more stress and depression symptoms and a greater accumulation of symptoms than did the pilot groups employed by the stable airlines.</excerpt>

title: Proceedings of the Human Factors Society 34th Annual Meeting - Orlando '90
doc: <title>Proceedings of the Human Factors Society 34th Annual Meeting - Orlando '90</title> <excerpt>This conference proceedings, the second of two volumes, contains 174 papers on applications of human factors research. Topics discussed include international technology transfer, organizational design and management, personality and individual differences in human performance, protective equipment and safety warnings, highway and aviation safety, system development and upgrading, performance testing and evaluation, task performance training, visual performance assessment and cognitive processing..</excerpt>

title: A retrospective study of marital discord in pilots: The USAFSAM experience
doc: <title>A retrospective study of marital discord in pilots: The USAFSAM experience</title> <excerpt>This exploratory retrospective multi-case study investigates marital discord in USAF pilots as part of an overall concern with mission safety. Seventeen USAF School of Aerospace Medicine (USAFSAM) cases involving marital distress were reviwed, using a standardized format. Duration of martial discord ranged from 1-10 years with an average of 2.25 years.</excerpt>

title: Accident Simulation as a New Therapy Technique for Post‐ Traumatic Stress Disorder: A case study
doc: <title>Accident Simulation as a New Therapy Technique for Post‐ Traumatic Stress Disorder: A case study</title> <excerpt>ABSTRACT Data are presented from clinical interviews and psychological tests of a helicopter pilot who had survived a helicopter crash. Within a week, the pilot developed severe stress reactions after the crash, dominated by guilt feelings, nightmares and fear of not being able to fly. Helicopter‐accident training simulating a helicopter crashing into the water was used as part of the treatment.</excerpt>

title: The impact of a military air disaster on the health of assistance workers: A prospective study
doc: <title>The impact of a military air disaster on the health of assistance workers: A prospective study</title> <excerpt>The worst peacetime disaster in United States Army history occurred on December 12, 1985 in Gander, Newfoundland. A charter airline carrying 248 soldiers home from peacekeeping duties in the Sinai Desert crashed after a refueling stop, killing all on board. After the crash, Army family assistance workers were appointed to help the surviving family members of each dead soldier.</excerpt>

title: Adjustment of sleep and the circadian temperature rhythm after flights across nine time zones
doc: <title>Adjustment of sleep and the circadian temperature rhythm after flights across nine time zones</title> <excerpt>The adjustment of sleep-wake patterns and the circadian temperature rhythm was monitored in nine Royal Norwegian Airforce volunteers operating P-3 aircraft during a westward training deployment across nine time zones. Subjects recorded all sleep and nap times, rated nightly sleep quality, and completed personality inventories. Rectal temperature, heart rate, and wrist activity were continuously monitored.</excerpt>

title: Selected papers from the Fourth Symposium on Aviation Psychology: I
doc: <title>Selected papers from the Fourth Symposium on Aviation Psychology: I</title>

title: A long‐term psychosocial follow‐up study of burned adults
doc: <title>A long‐term psychosocial follow‐up study of burned adults</title> <excerpt>ABSTRACT A clinical psychiatric follow‐up study of 70 burned adults was performed 3–13 years after the burn injury. The majority of patients had minor injuries. Twenty‐three percent suffered from definite psychosocial problems at follow up.</excerpt>

title: Decision-Making in the International Civil Aviation Organization: Politics, Processes and Personalities

title: Personal characteristics related to accident histories of Canadian pilots
doc: <title>Personal characteristics related to accident histories of Canadian pilots</title> <excerpt>Over 8,800 returns of a questionnaire, distributed to Canadian pilots, were analyzed. Items were chiefly about life events, hobbies, humour, and characteristics which might bear on susceptibility to 'pilot error' accidents. Sets of items were compiled which discriminated whether or nor respondents had had an aircraft accident in the past 10 years.</excerpt>

doc: <title>A long-term psychosocial follow-up study of burned adults</title> <excerpt>A clinical psychiatric follow-up study of 70 burned adults was performed 3-13 years after the burn injury. The majority of patients had minor injuries. Twenty-three percent suffered from definite psychosocial problems at follow up.</excerpt>

title: Importance Of Specialized Cognitive Function In The Selecti
doc: <title>Importance Of Specialized Cognitive Function In The Selecti</title> <excerpt>A study followed the careers of student aviators from the US Navy after cognitive testing to determine if visuospatial tests would identify potential failures. Tests of specialized cognitive function were given to 600 student naval aviators in early stages of their training. Those in the sample had been preselected for flight school and were expected to succeed in the training program.</excerpt>

title: The aviation psychology program at RAF Upper Heyford
doc: <title>The aviation psychology program at RAF Upper Heyford</title> <excerpt>An Aviation Psychology Program was started in September, 1985 at RAF Upper Heyford, with the focus on teaching flight commanders and their wives to recognize and deal with aircrew member and family stress. The overall goal is to prevent aircraft accidents and mishaps caused by human factor errors. Case reports are presented which demonstrate the value of the aviation psychologist becoming integrated in the flying community.</excerpt>

title: The psychological health and stress of pilots in a labor dispute
doc: <title>The psychological health and stress of pilots in a labor dispute</title> <excerpt>This study investigated the psychological stress and psychiatric symptomatology in a representative sample of pilots involved in a labor dispute with management. Standardized epidemiological psychometric instruments revealed that one quarter of the piltos could be labelled 'psychologically at risk' showing elevated symptoms of anger-hostility, paranoia, and obsessive-compulsiveness. A certain combination of personality scores with stress reactions was found to correctly classify pilots who were healthy vs 'at risk' with 92% accuracy.</excerpt>

title: Adult children of alcoholics - A treatable entity: An aviation case report
doc: <title>Adult children of alcoholics - A treatable entity: An aviation case report</title> <excerpt>This is a case report of a male naval aviator, raised in an alcoholic environment, and the impact of that environment on his development and adult functioning. A review of the adult children of alcoholics syndrome is presented to help familiarize the reader with this evolving entity and its probable impact on aviation personnel. In the United States, current estimates indicate that parental alcoholism affects 27 million children.</excerpt>

title: Increase in the effectiveness of shaping flight habits with the use of a G-load simulation system in the trainer; O povyshenii éffektivnosti formirovaniia letnykh navykov s pomoshch'iu sistemy imitatsii peregruzok na trenazhere.
doc: <title>Increase in the effectiveness of shaping flight habits with the use of a G-load simulation system in the trainer; O povyshenii éffektivnosti formirovaniia letnykh navykov s pomoshch'iu sistemy imitatsii peregruzok na trenazhere.</title>

title: Primary Prevention in Aircraft Disasters: Integrating Research and Practice
doc: <title>Primary Prevention in Aircraft Disasters: Integrating Research and Practice</title> <excerpt>The integration of rigorous scientific research with program development and implementation is essential in new areas of psychological practice, such as primary prevention for aircraft disaster victims. Research on primary prevention for air disasters can provide practical information on how to help victims cope with traumatic events, as well as contributing to theoretical understanding about the role of trauma in the development of psychopathology. Both epidemiological research on the mental health effects of disasters and practitioner experiences are used in this article to identify high risk groups and types of primary prevention interventions for air disasters.</excerpt>

title: An Airport Director's Perspective on Disaster Planning and Mental Health Needs
doc: <title>An Airport Director's Perspective on Disaster Planning and Mental Health Needs</title> <excerpt>The Director of the Minneapolis/St. Paul International Airport describes the responsibilities of major airports in disaster planning and response, including mental health needs. He discusses the impact of changes in the industry on airports' disaster plans, relevant Federal Aviation Administration regulations, and typical features of airport disaster plans.</excerpt>

title: The Neglected Entity in Air Disaster Planning: Psychological Services
doc: <title>The Neglected Entity in Air Disaster Planning: Psychological Services</title> <excerpt>Psychological services for air disaster victims have been neglected in past airport and airline crash response programs. This article explores the psychological impact of air disasters on passengers and airline employees, highlighting the victims' emotional needs following a crash. Organizational efforts that have been implemented to address human problems resulting from air crashes are surveyed.</excerpt>

title: Correction of the body function of flight instructors in aviation schools during intensive flights; Korrektsiia funktsional'nogo sostoianiia organizma letchikov-instruktorov aviatsionnykh uchilishch v period intensivnykh poletov.
doc: <title>Correction of the body function of flight instructors in aviation schools during intensive flights; Korrektsiia funktsional'nogo sostoianiia organizma letchikov-instruktorov aviatsionnykh uchilishch v period intensivnykh poletov.</title>

title: Perspective flight path displays: application of ergonomically driven display design principles
doc: <title>Perspective flight path displays: application of ergonomically driven display design principles</title> <excerpt>The authors describe the steps that have been taken to design and evaluate a 4-D perspective flight path predictor display. This description is based heavily on psychological theory in an effort to show how basic principles of human performance can and should guide design decisions in display formulation. In particular, five fundamental principles or properties of human ergonomics and performance have guided the choice of the display configurations to incorporate and evaluate working memory limitations, object integrality, compatibility, consistency, and visual momentum.</excerpt>

title: A psychophysiological assessment of operator workload during simulated flight missions
doc: <title>A psychophysiological assessment of operator workload during simulated flight missions</title> <excerpt>Previous research has indicated that components of the event-related potential (ERP) may be used to quantify the resource requirements of complex cognitive tasks. The present study was designed to explore the degree to which these results could be generalized to complex, real-world tasks. The study also examined the relations among performance-based, subjective, and psychophysiological measures of operator workload.</excerpt>

title: The Prospective impact of psychosocial variables on rates of illness and injury in professional employees
doc: <title>The Prospective impact of psychosocial variables on rates of illness and injury in professional employees</title> <excerpt>From a prospective study of health changes in air traffic controllers, it was determined that high scores on self-report measures of work-related life change distress, other life changes outside the worksetting, the type A behavior pattern, and dissatisfaction with management were positively related to future rates of injuries and physician-diagnosed acute illness episodes. Depending on the risk factor involved, high scorers on these psychosocial risk predictors incurred from 80% to 252% more future accidental injuries and from 38% to 69% wore future total morbidity over a 27-month follow-up period than the men in the low scoring groups. Moreover, coworkerrated amicability, probably an indication of the amount of social support available to an individual, was significantly protective against these outcome variables, with the rarely or never chosen group experiencing 60% more total morbidity and 174% more injuries than the often chosen group.</excerpt>

title: The healthy motivation to fly: No psychiatric diagnosis
doc: <title>The healthy motivation to fly: No psychiatric diagnosis</title> <excerpt>Aircrew mission effectiveness may uniquely be influenced by subtle psychological factors not ordinarily brought to the attention of psychiatrists. Pilots tend to be bright, articulate, and anxious to resume their aviation duties when grounded. However, these patients are usually well defended, and rarely psychologically attuned or introspective.</excerpt>

title: Relation between the personality traits of athletes and the quality of their parachute jumps; Vzaimosviaz' mezhdu osobennostiami lichnosti sportsmenov i kachestvom vypolneniia parashiutnykh pryzhkov.
doc: <title>Relation between the personality traits of athletes and the quality of their parachute jumps; Vzaimosviaz' mezhdu osobennostiami lichnosti sportsmenov i kachestvom vypolneniia parashiutnykh pryzhkov.</title>

title: The visual stress model-A psycho-physiological method for the evaluation of operational reliability of pilots and cosmonauts
doc: <title>The visual stress model-A psycho-physiological method for the evaluation of operational reliability of pilots and cosmonauts</title> <excerpt>An experimental psycho-physiological method is presented for the evaluation of visual-cognitive performance preconditions and operational reliability of pilots and cosmonauts. As visual-cognitive stress are used tachistoscopically presented instrument symbols under conditions of individual speed of work and time pressure. The results of the compared extreme groups consisting of pilots with good and insufficient flight performance showed that the pilots with impairments to the quality of flight activity differ already before the test in their individual habitual characteristics and actual motivation, during the stress in their operational parameters, in the dimensions of their cardiorespiratory activation as well as in their efficiency and after the stress in their subjective experience of the stress.</excerpt>

title: The Macy Reports: Combat fatigue in World War II fliers
doc: <title>The Macy Reports: Combat fatigue in World War II fliers</title> <excerpt>Having supported psychiatric investigation into the psychosomatic aspects of 'war neurosis' since 1931, the Josiah Macy, Jr., Foundation published five volumes on combat fatigue and its prophylaxis, recognition, treatment, and administrative aspects during World War II. The five volumes were as follows: 'War Neuroses in North Africa,' by R.R. Grinker and J.P.</excerpt>

title: HISTORY OF THE AERONAUTICAL RESEARCH COUNCIL; A PERSONAL VIEW.
doc: <title>HISTORY OF THE AERONAUTICAL RESEARCH COUNCIL; A PERSONAL VIEW.</title> <excerpt>This informal history of the Aeronautical Research Council begins with a brief outline of its establishment in 1909. The author then discusses the subsequent growth and widening of its research activites for the advancement of aircraft design and construction, particularly around the two great wars, and finally its gradual decline until brought to a close in 1980. The story is told from a personal viewpoint and touches on the many personalities involved..</excerpt>

doc: <title>Effect of a short-term exposure to carbon monoxide high concentrations on man's psychophysiological functions</title>

title: Scientific-theoretical problems in the rationale for the system of sociopsychological selection of flight crews; Nauchno-teoreticheskie problemy obosnovaniia sistemy sotsial'no-psikhologicheskogo otbora letnogo sostava.
doc: <title>Scientific-theoretical problems in the rationale for the system of sociopsychological selection of flight crews; Nauchno-teoreticheskie problemy obosnovaniia sistemy sotsial'no-psikhologicheskogo otbora letnogo sostava.</title> <excerpt>A large number of flight accidents and catastrophes associated with the human factor, high nervous and psychic tension when being on duty, increasing trend towards a greater incidence of psychogenic diseases responsible for pilots to be grounded make it necessary to develop a system of primary psychoprophylaxis of the flying personnel and to help them with various social, psychohygienic and psychoprophylactic measures. This paper presents basic psychoprophylactic measures of medical expertise, professional training and psychological selection. Proper development of these measures will contribute to flight safety and pilot longevity..</excerpt>

title: The visual stress model--a psycho-physiological method for the evaluation of operational reliability of pilots and cosmonauts
doc: <title>The visual stress model--a psycho-physiological method for the evaluation of operational reliability of pilots and cosmonauts</title> <excerpt>An experimental psycho-physiological method is presented for the evaluation of visual-cognitive performance preconditions and operational reliability of pilots and cosmonauts. As visual-cognitive stress are used tachistoscopically presented instrument symbols under conditions of individual speed of work and time pressure. The results of the compared extreme groups consisting of pilots with good and insufficient flight performance showed that the pilots with impairments to the quality of flight activity differ already before the test in their individual habitual characteristics and actual motivation, during the stress in their operational parameters, in the dimensions of their cardiorespiratory activation as well as in their efficiency and after the stress in their subjective experience of the stress.</excerpt>

title: A review of the psychological aspects of space flight
doc: <title>A review of the psychological aspects of space flight</title> <excerpt>Instances of overt, serious functional impairment of space crews caused by adverse psychologic responses have not been scientifically documented. However, transient disorientation, spatial illusions, and visual disturbances as well as anomalous myopias, sleep disturbances, and instances of substandard performance have been described. Moreover, anecdotal information describes significant psychologic aberrations in space flight.</excerpt>

title: A Review of the Medical Standards for Civilian Airmen: Synopsis of a Two-Year Study
doc: <title>A Review of the Medical Standards for Civilian Airmen: Synopsis of a Two-Year Study</title> <excerpt>This article summarizes the report of a comprehensive review by the American Medical Association (AMA) of the medical standards for civilian airmen. The present standards were promulgated by the Federal Aviation Administration in 1959; the alcoholism and cardiovascular standards were revised in 1982. The AMA report recommends new or revised standards for cardiovascular, mental and behavioral, visual, endocrine, respiratory, hematological, hearing and equilibrium, musculoskeletal, and nervous system disorders.</excerpt>

title: Use of a Behavior-Based Personality Instrument in Aviation Selection
doc: <title>Use of a Behavior-Based Personality Instrument in Aviation Selection</title> <excerpt>This study evaluated a behavioral-based personality instrument currently used by a branch of the United States Armed Forces in their experimental aviation selection battery. The instrument, the Dot Estimation Task (DOT), was designed to measure compulsiveness versus decisiveness. The reliability and validity of this experimental instrument was evaluated.</excerpt>

title: Marital adjustment and personality in aviation-rated and nonrated warrant officers.
doc: <title>Marital adjustment and personality in aviation-rated and nonrated warrant officers.</title>

title: Possibilities and limits of using speech signals in aviation and space psychophysiology.
doc: <title>Possibilities and limits of using speech signals in aviation and space psychophysiology.</title>

title: Back to basics: suggested solutions to some flight instruction problems
doc: <title>Back to basics: suggested solutions to some flight instruction problems</title> <excerpt>Since 1976 a series of surveys of flight instructors and students in general and commercial aviation, and the Royal Australian Air Force, has indicated several common problems in flight instruction. These problems have provided a focus for instructor education programs described in this paper. Professional preparation of instructions in areas such as educational psychology (learning and memory, motivation, and skill acquisition) met with the approval of the participants, but no detectable change in instructional methods resulted.</excerpt>

title: Color discrimination as a function of saturation, field size, and adaptation level
doc: <title>Color discrimination as a function of saturation, field size, and adaptation level</title> <excerpt>The purpose of our research was to investigate color discrimination under conditions of ambient illumination that may reduce CRT display saturation and contrast. Our research measured both the variability of color matching and the offsets from a match necessary for a 100% discrimination difference. We did this for four dominant wavelengths each at five saturation levels.</excerpt>

title: Bigness is in the eye of the beholder
doc: <title>Bigness is in the eye of the beholder</title> <excerpt>This report reviews an investigation of judgments of size and distance as required of pilots in flight. The experiments covered a broad spectrum of basic psychophysiological issues involving the measurement of visual accomodation and its correlation with various other dependent variables. Psychophysiological issues investigated included the size-distance invariance hypothesis, the projection of afterimages, the moon illusion, night and empty-field myopia, the dark focus and its so-called Mandelbaum effect, the nature and locus of the accomodative stimulus, the relation between accomodation, retinal size, and perceived size, and possible relationships among accomodative responses, autonomic balance, and personality variables.; This report reviews an investigation of judgements of size and distance as required of pilots in flight.</excerpt>

title: GLOC AND DISORIENTATION CRITICAL AREAS IN AEROSPACE PHYSIOLOGY TODAY.
doc: <title>GLOC AND DISORIENTATION CRITICAL AREAS IN AEROSPACE PHYSIOLOGY TODAY.</title> <excerpt>The panel emphasizes the safety aspects of the problems; R&D and physiological training involvement; and presents up to date research and development efforts, including improved aircraft and life support equipment to support the aircrew. It should be noted that, while aircrafts have undergone drastic changes since the beginning of aviation man has not| It is pointed out that physiological training is only one of the ways to inform and train the aircrews on these hazards. Additional areas include instrument courses, squadron briefings, videotapes of inflight, and improved equipment..</excerpt>

title: Trends in the work of the aviation physician; O nekotorykh napravleniiakh raboty aviatsionnogo vracha.
doc: <title>Trends in the work of the aviation physician; O nekotorykh napravleniiakh raboty aviatsionnogo vracha.</title>

title: ROLE OF SAFETY ENGINEERING IN PRODUCT DEVELOPMENT: IMPROVING THE MANAGEMENT/TECHNICAL INTERFACE.
doc: <title>ROLE OF SAFETY ENGINEERING IN PRODUCT DEVELOPMENT: IMPROVING THE MANAGEMENT/TECHNICAL INTERFACE.</title> <excerpt>In order to be effective, the safety professional must develop a perception of safety engineering, by other management and professional elements in the design process, of contribution and worth in the development of the enterprise. This paper presents a methodology for understanding the relationship between behavior and perception, assessing the level of conflict within the design and management environment, and developing optional behaviors to influence the perceptions of safety engineering by others within the work unit. The model specified in the paper is an adaptation of control theory utilized with marked success in the psychology community.</excerpt>

title: Principles of S-C-R compatibility with spatial and verbal tasks: The role of display-control location and voice-interactive display-control interfacing
doc: <title>Principles of S-C-R compatibility with spatial and verbal tasks: The role of display-control location and voice-interactive display-control interfacing</title> <excerpt>A pilot's tasks may be categorized into those that demand predominantly verbal operations and those that are spatial. We describe two experiments that define two principles of compatibility of interfacing such tasks with displays and controls. The first, based upon hemispheric laterality effects, defines compatibility according to the display location and the response hand; the second defines compatibility according to the modality of display (auditory and visual) and response (manual and speech).</excerpt>

title: AVIATION PSYCHOLOGY (SELECTED PAPERS PRESENTED AT THE SECOND SYMPOSIUM).
doc: <title>AVIATION PSYCHOLOGY (SELECTED PAPERS PRESENTED AT THE SECOND SYMPOSIUM).</title> <excerpt>This conference proceedings contains ten papers on aviation psychology and applications of human factors principles to the aviation environment. The papers show that the field goes far beyond psychology alone. Aviation psychology encompasses engineering, psychology, physiology and training; the papers presented treat subjects as diverse as the effect of pilot judgment and pilot error on workload and stress, the design of simulations of in-flight crises, the design of the cockpit, the impact of management styles on crew coordination, and the history of aviation psychology in war and peace.</excerpt>

title: Medico-psychological problems of the occupational fitness of flight personnel; Mediko-psikhologicheskie voprosy professional'noǐ nadezhnosti letnogo sostava.
doc: <title>Medico-psychological problems of the occupational fitness of flight personnel; Mediko-psikhologicheskie voprosy professional'noǐ nadezhnosti letnogo sostava.</title>

title: Application of a multifactor approach to transfer of training research
doc: <title>Application of a multifactor approach to transfer of training research</title> <excerpt>A multifactor, multicriterion transfer of training experiment involving a computer-generated horizontal tracking task was conducted to establish relationships among training and transfer scores for manual control of a maneuvering vehicle, to determine the response surfaces for training and transfer, and to demonstrate a new transfer research paradigm that makes economically feasible the simultaneous investigation of the effects of a large number of training-equipment and use variables on transfer to multiple-criterion vehicle configurations. There were 80 experimental participants, 48 of whom were trained and tested on individually unique combinations of training and transfer conditions. This study measures the training and transfer effects of as many as six training equipment and use factors in a single experiment, to examine as many as 25 training-vehicle configurations in the same experiment, to train a single individual on each of 48 training conditions, to employ multiple (3) transfer vehicle configurations, and to provide data suitable for deriving multiple-regression equations for estimating the transfer effectiveness of configurations not directly studied.; A multifactor, multicriterion transfer of training experiment involving a computer-generated horizontal tracking task was conducted to establish relationships among training and transfer scores for manual control of a maneuvering vehicle, to determine the response surfaces for training and transfer, and to demonstrate a new transfer research paradigm that makes economically feasible the simultaneous investigation of the effects of a large number of training-equipment and use variables on transfer to multiple-criterion vehicle configurations.</excerpt>

title: Computer-aided testing of pilot response to critical in-flight events
doc: <title>Computer-aided testing of pilot response to critical in-flight events</title> <excerpt>This research on pilot response to critical in-flight events employs a unique methodology including an interactive computer-aided scenario-testing system. Navigation displays, instrument-panel displays, and assorted textual material are presented on a touch-sensitive CRT screen. Problem diagnosis scenarios, destination-diversion scenarios and combined destination/diagnostic tests are available.</excerpt>

title: An investigation of the effectiveness of pilot judgment training
doc: <title>An investigation of the effectiveness of pilot judgment training</title> <excerpt>Pilot decisional errors have always been a significant factor in aviation accidents. Pilot judgment, however, traditionally has been viewed as an intrinsic quality or a by-product of flying experience. Only recently has it been examined as a potential flight-training requirement.</excerpt>

title: Characteristics of the medical support for aviation and space flight; Nekotorye osobennosti meditsinskogo obespecheniia aviatsionnykh i kosmicheskikh poletov.
doc: <title>Characteristics of the medical support for aviation and space flight; Nekotorye osobennosti meditsinskogo obespecheniia aviatsionnykh i kosmicheskikh poletov.</title> <excerpt>Comparison of the specific features of the environment and human activities in aviation and space flights allows us to distinguish the major relations in the system man--vehicle--environment as related to their medical support. It is concluded that in the aviation flight the man-vehicle interaction plays the leading role while in the space flight the man-environment interaction comes to the foreground. Having in view these differences, medical and professional selection, prediction, medical monitoring and medical support of pilots and cosmonauts are discussed..</excerpt>

title: Neuropsychiatric symptoms in workers occupationally exposed to jet fuel — a combined epidemiological and casuistic study
doc: <title>Neuropsychiatric symptoms in workers occupationally exposed to jet fuel — a combined epidemiological and casuistic study</title> <excerpt>Some aircraft personell and airline industry workers are exposed to jet fuel, a mixture of aliphatic hydrocarbons (petroleum 80%) and some organic solvents (aromatic hydrocarbons 20%). In order to evaluate the possible neuropsychiatric sequale of such long‐term occupational exposure, we examined 30 workers exposed at about 250 mg/m3 for 4—32 years at a jet motor factory. They were compared with two control groups (2 × 30) of matched non‐exposed workers.</excerpt>

title: Psychological well-being in united states air force fliers
doc: <title>Psychological well-being in united states air force fliers</title> <excerpt>Three dimensions of overall health are defined by the World Health Organization-physical, mental, and social. Psychological well-being has been a popular research topic recently and has been shown to relate to mental health. The analysis of distinct population groups offers unique opportunities for the investigation of the interplay of the psychological, social, and physical elements of health.</excerpt>

title: Psychophysiology of tourism pilots; Sulla psicofisiologia dei piloti da turismo.
doc: <title>Psychophysiology of tourism pilots; Sulla psicofisiologia dei piloti da turismo.</title>

doc: <title>Achievements of aviation medicine--practical implications; Dostizheniia aviatsionnoǐ meditsiny - v praktiku.</title>

title: Locus of control, self-serving biases, and attitudes towards safety in general aviation pilots
doc: <title>Locus of control, self-serving biases, and attitudes towards safety in general aviation pilots</title> <excerpt>Of the three related survey studies that were conducted, two are summarized and one, which characterizes all three, is reported in detail. The studies attempted to determine how aviators compared with the general population on the personality dimension - locus of control (internal vs external) and how this was related to aviators' attenance at FAA Safety Clinics. In addition, aviators were surveyed regarding their attituds towards safety, their flying skill, and the likelihood that they would have an accident during the remainder of their careers.</excerpt>

title: Selected papers from the First International Symposium on Aviation Psychology: III.
doc: <title>Selected papers from the First International Symposium on Aviation Psychology: III.</title>

title: The role of communications, socio-psychological, and personality factors in the maintenance of crew coordination
doc: <title>The role of communications, socio-psychological, and personality factors in the maintenance of crew coordination</title> <excerpt>There is increasing evidence that many air transport incidents and accidents are the result of the improper or inadequate utilization of the resources accessible to flight deck crew members. These resources obviously include the hardware and technical information necessary for the safe and efficient conduct of the flight, but they also include the human resources which must be coordinated effectively. The focus of this paper is upon the human resources, and how communication styles, socio-psychological factors, and personality characteristics can affect crew coordination..</excerpt>

title: Functional optical invariants: A new methodology for aviation research
doc: <title>Functional optical invariants: A new methodology for aviation research</title> <excerpt>The application to aviation physiology of Gibson's 'ecological approach to visual perception' demands information-rich visual displays to adequately and unambiguously enable a pilot to perform flight maneuvers. Optical information often takes the form of invariant properties of a changing optic array, and functional invariants are defined as psychologically effective optical invariants. Their effectiveness is determined by empirical test, but standard experimental paradigms are shown to be inappropriate for testing the effectiveness of information-rich displays.</excerpt>

title: Selected papers from the First International Symposium on Aviation Psychology: I.
doc: <title>Selected papers from the First International Symposium on Aviation Psychology: I.</title>

title: Variations in the health state of heavy transport helicopter pilots during flight shifts
doc: <title>Variations in the health state of heavy transport helicopter pilots during flight shifts</title> <excerpt>Before and after flights about 300 crewmembers of heavy transport helicopters were examined using psychophysiological and integral methods that yield professionally important information. During a flight shift the health state of helicopter pilots varies via three stages: habituation, initial decline and distinct lassitude, with the latter developing after 5 h flight load. In order to increase human reliability in the pilot-helicopter system, it is advisable to allow 4 h flight time during a flight shift or board helicopters of the above type.</excerpt>

title: A method for investigating human factor aspects of aircraft accidents and incidents
doc: <title>A method for investigating human factor aspects of aircraft accidents and incidents</title> <excerpt>Approximately 70% of aircraft accidents and incidents have in the past been attributed to human error, and the importance of human error as a major contributory factor is now universally recognized. A satisfactory technique for the investigation of human error type accidents and incidents has not yet been standardized. This paper describes a comprehensive procedure which has been designed to assess human behaviour in instances of aircraft accidents and incidents.</excerpt>

title: Psychophysiological and other factors affecting human performance in accident prevention and investigation
doc: <title>Psychophysiological and other factors affecting human performance in accident prevention and investigation</title> <excerpt>Psychophysiological factors are not uncommon terms in the aviation incident/accident investigation sequence where human error is involved. It is highly suspect that the same psychophysiological factors may also exist in the industrial arena where operator personnel function; but, there is little evidence in literature indicating how management and subordinates cope with these factors to prevent or reduce accidents. It is apparent that 'human factors' psychophysiological training is quite evident in the aviation industry.</excerpt>

title: Identification of features associated with flying phobia in aircrew
doc: <title>Identification of features associated with flying phobia in aircrew</title> <excerpt>The psychological and physiological features of 20 aircrew consecutively referred for treatment of anxiety symptoms when flying were compared with a matched control group of uncomplaining aircrew. There were no significant differences between the two groups on psychometric tests of personality, though there were differences in skin conductance; the phobics had a higher rate of spontaneous fluctuation, and habituated less to a repeated auditory tone. More of the phobic group worried about their wives and acknowledged childhood and other adulthood phobias; more had a family history of an episode perhaps best described as flying trauma.</excerpt>

title: Space flight and the development of aviation medicine; Kosmonautika i razvitie aviatsionnoǐ meditsiny.
doc: <title>Space flight and the development of aviation medicine; Kosmonautika i razvitie aviatsionnoǐ meditsiny.</title> <excerpt>The paper discusses certain aspects of interaction between aviation and space medicine, contribution of aviation medicine into the development of space biology and medicine, and the role of cosmonautics in current achievements of aviation medicine. The paper describes advances in studies of space flight effects, development of life support and flight safety systems, medical and psychological support of the flight personnel, implementation of new methods and techniques, electronics, computers and automatics. Particular importance is attached to the rapid development of ergonomic approaches to the design and application of new technology, study of psychophysiology and psychology of human efficient activity in the system "man--flying vehicle--environment", i.</excerpt>

title: Psychophysiological selection: status and prospects; Psikhofiziologicheskiǐ otbor: sostoianie i perspektivy.
doc: <title>Psychophysiological selection: status and prospects; Psikhofiziologicheskiǐ otbor: sostoianie i perspektivy.</title> <excerpt>The major stages in the development of psychophysiological selection of cosmonauts in the USSR are discussed. The psychophysiological selection was originally based on the data of psychoneurological expertise of the flight personnel and achievements of aviation psychology in the USSR. This was followed by the development of psychophysiological research, using instrumentation and simulation flights.</excerpt>

title: Causes of fatigue in civil aviation helicopter crews; O prichinakh utomleniia ékipazheǐ vertoletov grazhdanskoǐ aviatsii.
doc: <title>Causes of fatigue in civil aviation helicopter crews; O prichinakh utomleniia ékipazheǐ vertoletov grazhdanskoǐ aviatsii.</title> <excerpt>Vibration and noise play an important part in fatiguing crewmembers of helicopters. The exposure to these factors during the flying shift results in an early and marked fatigue of pilots the level of which depends on the vibration effects to a larger extent than on the noise effects. The fatigue is followed by a decline of the psychophysiological parameters characterizing the visual and motor functions as well as the ratio of the basic processes in the central nervous system..</excerpt>

title: An information-processing interpretation of air traffic control stress
doc: <title>An information-processing interpretation of air traffic control stress</title> <excerpt>The air traffic controller's job is inherently stressful, resulting in a variety of stress-related symptoms and illnesses. Unusually high information-processing demands are placed upon controllers for extended periods of time, so that they often must work close to the limits of their channel capacity. The effort required to process information, maintain continuous concentration, and render timely and reasonable decisions is likely to be very stressful.</excerpt>

title: Psychological compatibility on Earth and in outer space
doc: <title>Psychological compatibility on Earth and in outer space</title>

title: The autogenous training in the psychophysiological preparation for parachute jumping; AUTOGENES TRAINING BEI DER PSYCHOPHYSIOLOGISCHEN VORBEREITUNG AUF FALLSCHIRMSPRUNGE
doc: <title>The autogenous training in the psychophysiological preparation for parachute jumping; AUTOGENES TRAINING BEI DER PSYCHOPHYSIOLOGISCHEN VORBEREITUNG AUF FALLSCHIRMSPRUNGE</title> <excerpt>The health conditions required for participants in military sports are similar to those required for draftees and career officers. In principle, the fitness for all branches of military sports can be evaluated by any physician in the framework of the prophylactic care on an outpatient basis, as far as these tasks are delegated by the district medical officer. All persons practising sports must be examined every year for fitness for sports.</excerpt>

title: Investigation of life change as a contributing factor in aircraft accidents: A prospectus
doc: <title>Investigation of life change as a contributing factor in aircraft accidents: A prospectus</title> <excerpt>The author presents a personal perspective on attempts to reduce aircraft accidents resulting from human failure in the cockpit. The premise is that accidents result from an imbalance between performance ability and performance demand. Advances in decreasing pilot-induced accidents must come from methods that will prevent the stresses that diminish performance ability.</excerpt>

title: The psychiatrist confronted with psychosomatic disorders in aviators; LE PSYCHIATRE DEVANT LES TROUBLES PSYCHOSOMATIQUES DU PERSONNEL NAVIGANT
doc: <title>The psychiatrist confronted with psychosomatic disorders in aviators; LE PSYCHIATRE DEVANT LES TROUBLES PSYCHOSOMATIQUES DU PERSONNEL NAVIGANT</title> <excerpt>The author, a psychiatrist studying psychodynamic orientation, sees the pilot's personality as a relatively durable one, the characteristics of which are the product of the mutual interaction between the individual and his social environment and which manifests itself in the pilot's behavior and socioprofessional adaptation. Psychotherapeutic opinion applies equally to the aviation authorities and the pilot. The best time to start treating psychosomatic complaints is during the 'non-organised' psychosomatic phase..</excerpt>

title: Complex evaluation of the individual psychological characteristics of flight personnel in medical aviation expertise; Kompleksnaia otsenka individual'no-psikhologicheskikh osobennosteǐ letnogo sostava pri vrachebno-letnoǐ ékspertize.
doc: <title>Complex evaluation of the individual psychological characteristics of flight personnel in medical aviation expertise; Kompleksnaia otsenka individual'no-psikhologicheskikh osobennosteǐ letnogo sostava pri vrachebno-letnoǐ ékspertize.</title>

doc: <title>Aviation physician and light work; Aviatsionnyǐ vrach i letnaia rabota.</title>

title: The effect of propranolol on human psychomotor performance
doc: <title>The effect of propranolol on human psychomotor performance</title> <excerpt>Despite their widespread usage the effect of beta blockers on human performance has been only sparsely studied and results of investigations are discrepant. This study examines the effect of one of the most commonly prescribed beta adrenergic blocking drugs, propranolol, on psychomotor function. To demonstrate the sensitivity of the test method and to provide some basis for comparison, the effect of small doses of sodium amylobarbitone on psychomotor performance is also measured.</excerpt>

title: Freudian theories and aviation psychology; TEORIE FREUDIANE E PSICOLOGIA AERONAUTICA
doc: <title>Freudian theories and aviation psychology; TEORIE FREUDIANE E PSICOLOGIA AERONAUTICA</title> <excerpt>A concise survey of Freud's theoretic concepts is performed, in relation to the phallic equivalence of aircraft. The author puts into evidence the fact that such theorization is a merely an intuitional one. Besides, it is clearly derived from Freud's cultural background.</excerpt>

title: Contribution to the history of doctrinaire evolution concerning the psychological selection of aircraft pilots in Italy; CONTRIBUTO ALLA STORIA DELL'EVOLUZIONE DOTTRINARIA IN TEMA DI SELEZIONE PSICOLOGICA DEL PILOTA DI AEREO IN ITALIA
doc: <title>Contribution to the history of doctrinaire evolution concerning the psychological selection of aircraft pilots in Italy; CONTRIBUTO ALLA STORIA DELL'EVOLUZIONE DOTTRINARIA IN TEMA DI SELEZIONE PSICOLOGICA DEL PILOTA DI AEREO IN ITALIA</title> <excerpt>A survey has been made as to the different stages of the theory of doctrinaire evolution for the psychological selection of aircraft pilots in Italy, from the initial poli-aptitude conception, of a deterministic model implying a concept of psycho-aptitude unfitness, to the most recent correlationalistic-inferential theories having a probabilistic character, implying the inadmissibility of such a concept..</excerpt>

title: Investigation of life changes as a contributing factor in aircraft accidents: a prospectus
doc: <title>Investigation of life changes as a contributing factor in aircraft accidents: a prospectus</title> <excerpt>The author presents a personal perspective on attempts to reduce aircraft accidents resulting from human failure in the cockpit. The premise is that accidents result from an imbalance between performance ability and performance demand. Advances in decreasing pilot-induced accidents must come from methods that will prevent the stresses that diminish performance ability.</excerpt>

title: New ideas on the theme of psychological selection of the aircraft pilot; NUOVE IDEE IN TEMA DI SELEZIONE PSICOLOGICA DEL PILOTA DI AEREO
doc: <title>New ideas on the theme of psychological selection of the aircraft pilot; NUOVE IDEE IN TEMA DI SELEZIONE PSICOLOGICA DEL PILOTA DI AEREO</title> <excerpt>The authors regard the problem of the selection of aircraft pilots according to the criteria of probability and intellectualism rather than of aptitude, following a trend internationally approved, that is not to make judgments of unfitness on psychological basis. This criterion implies some changes in rules and regulations, which the authors discuss..</excerpt>

title: Flight fitness of pilots in their sixties: Clinical observations and medico-legal considerations; IDONEITA' AL VOLO DEL PILOTA ULTRASESSANTENNE: RILIEVI CLINICI E CONSIDERAZIONI MEDICO-LEGALI
doc: <title>Flight fitness of pilots in their sixties: Clinical observations and medico-legal considerations; IDONEITA' AL VOLO DEL PILOTA ULTRASESSANTENNE: RILIEVI CLINICI E CONSIDERAZIONI MEDICO-LEGALI</title> <excerpt>Data are reported of general and specialist character, particularly psychologic and neuropsychiatric, in relation to 30 subjects over 60 years old exercising flight activity of varying intensity, who have been observed by the author during the period April/October 1978 at the I.M.L. for the Air Force of Rome. A good number of the subjects under consideration has shown a professional capability which is still sufficiently valid - due to the experience achieved in many years of flying service and the practically total absence of emotional - affective disturbing factors - in spite of presenting a lack in the sensory, noetic and proficiency spheres, which varies from one subject to the next.</excerpt>

title: Contribution to the establishment of a general theory in the field of aviation psychology; CONTRIBUTO ALL'ELABORAZIONE DI UNA TEORIA GENERALE NEL CAMPO DELLA PSICOLOGIA AERONAUTICA
doc: <title>Contribution to the establishment of a general theory in the field of aviation psychology; CONTRIBUTO ALL'ELABORAZIONE DI UNA TEORIA GENERALE NEL CAMPO DELLA PSICOLOGIA AERONAUTICA</title> <excerpt>Starting from the basic assumption concerning intellective-perceptive processes, the main behaviours observed in the aviation environment can be classified in a single framework of intellectualistic nature. Therefore the whole aviation psychology should be considered as essentially concerning perception and thinking in flight. The validity of such a classification, however, depends on the assumption which constitutes their basis..</excerpt>

title: Comparison of three studies of aircraft noise and psychiatric hospital admissions conducted in the same area
doc: <title>Comparison of three studies of aircraft noise and psychiatric hospital admissions conducted in the same area</title> <excerpt>Two earlier studies conducted in the vicinity of London (Heathrow) Airport compared the rate of admissions to a psychiatric hospital from areas exposed to different levels of aircraft noise. Their methods and results were not identical. A third study, reported here, examined standardized rates of admission to the same hospital for a longer period and for a larger area divided into 4 bands of aircraft noise.</excerpt>

title: The current nosographic and clinical validity of flight phobias; ATTUALE VALIDITA NOSOGRAFICA E CLINICA DELLE FOBIE DA VOLO
doc: <title>The current nosographic and clinical validity of flight phobias; ATTUALE VALIDITA NOSOGRAFICA E CLINICA DELLE FOBIE DA VOLO</title> <excerpt>Recent trends in the development of aeronautical psychopathology are examined. It is shown that flight phobias, far from decreasing in the sense of morbidity or pathogenicity, are observed with increasing frequency. Current psychopathological assessments of such phobias are described, and the influence of the surroundings, flight itself, and the subject's underlying personality in their determination is examined.</excerpt>

title: Personality correlates in a sample of male nurses in the British Royal Air Force
doc: <title>Personality correlates in a sample of male nurses in the British Royal Air Force</title> <excerpt>This descriptive study provides data relevant to two currently popular views of the male nursing image. Firstly, that male nurses tend to prefer the more technological or administrative aspects of nursing and secondly, that they exhibit to an unusually high degree what are commonly thought of as being amongst the more feminine personality traits. The sample consisted of 91 male RAF nurses working in RAF hospitals, and was of predominantly English nationality.</excerpt>

title: Age-related changes of psychophysiological functions of civil pilots due to the vibration-noise effects
doc: <title>Age-related changes of psychophysiological functions of civil pilots due to the vibration-noise effects</title> <excerpt>The effect of vibration and noise of helicopters on the psychophysiological funcitons of their crew members was studied in relation to their age. The changes were mostly pronounced in pilots younger than 20-25 and older than 45 yr. The peculiar changes in the psychophysiological functions can be associated with the age-related features of adaptation to vibration and noise effects and with the different level of professional training..</excerpt>

title: Sociopsychological factors affecting the human response to noise exposure
doc: <title>Sociopsychological factors affecting the human response to noise exposure</title> <excerpt>Community noise is reported to be the most often mentioned undesirable neighborhood condition in a recent U.S.Census survey. Understanding community response to noise involves the measurement of a number of complex acoustic and nonacoustic variables and establishing the chain of relationships between physical exposure, perception, annoyance, and acceptability responses and finally complaint behavior. The perceived loudness of a noise is the most important acoustic parameter influencing annoyance and complaints, and the simple dBA unit can be used to integrate spectral characteristics of complex sounds in community studies.</excerpt>

doc: <title>Psychology of the development of special skills of action in flight contingency situations</title>

title: The deliberate use of sky diving in the achievement of key educational goals for individuals with environmentally created behavioral disorders; DER INTENTIONALE EINFLUSZ DES FALLSCHIRMSPORTS AUF NOTWENDIGE ERZIEHUNGSZIELE BEI MILIEUREAKTIVEN VERHALTENSSTORUNGEN
doc: <title>The deliberate use of sky diving in the achievement of key educational goals for individuals with environmentally created behavioral disorders; DER INTENTIONALE EINFLUSZ DES FALLSCHIRMSPORTS AUF NOTWENDIGE ERZIEHUNGSZIELE BEI MILIEUREAKTIVEN VERHALTENSSTORUNGEN</title> <excerpt>The influence of physical education as a special educational means is the subject of this longitudinal analysis. These activities included sport-parachuting (sky diving). The program was carried out with the special methods and techniques of social group work.</excerpt>

title: Successful transfer of adaptation acquired in a slow rotation room to motion environments in navy flight training
doc: <title>Successful transfer of adaptation acquired in a slow rotation room to motion environments in navy flight training</title> <excerpt>Two flight students, grounded for the reason they were highly susceptible to motion sickness, completed their training after gradually adapting to 10 rpm, achieved by executing head movements during small step-wise increases in angular velocity. Subject 1 executed a total of about 77 000 head movements within a period of 5 months and Subject 2 executed about 108000 head movements within a period of 42 days. The transfer of adaptation acquired in the laboratory to most motion environments aloft was good; the notable exception involved weightless maneuvers in the case of Subject 1.</excerpt>

title: Fliers mental health problems; PROBLEMES DE SANTE MENTALE EN MILIEU AERONAUTIQUE
doc: <title>Fliers mental health problems; PROBLEMES DE SANTE MENTALE EN MILIEU AERONAUTIQUE</title> <excerpt>A global study of fliers' mental health problems shows the importance of professional and psychological troubles as well as the relative rarity of psychiatric syndromes per se. The authors insist on the role of language (speech) and communication on mental health in an aeronautical environment. They also describe the function of the flight surgeons which to them is essential.</excerpt>

title: Speech intelligibility through communication headsets for general aviation
doc: <title>Speech intelligibility through communication headsets for general aviation</title> <excerpt>Word discrimination was measured on eight general aviation pilots listening alternately through each of three communication headsets and an aircraft loudspeaker in the presence of light aircraft noise. Each subject listened at the speech intensity designated by him as yielded optimal intelligibility. Performance varied directly with the degree of attenuation provided by the headset.</excerpt>

title: Emergency mental health services during and after a major aircraft accident
doc: <title>Emergency mental health services during and after a major aircraft accident</title> <excerpt>A major commercial aircraft accident mobilizes a sophisticated disaster response by the federal government and local disaster teams. However, there is no effort to deal with the significant mental health needs of survivors, airline crew, ground personnel, and rescuers. The time has come to deal with the human tragedy and its emotional consequences.</excerpt>

title: Psychophysiological characteristics of pilot performance during short-term exposures to intensive light stimuli
doc: <title>Psychophysiological characteristics of pilot performance during short-term exposures to intensive light stimuli</title> <excerpt>Psychophysiological characteristics of pilot performance were studied during short-term exposures to intensive light stimuli. The experiments were carried out in the laboratory and in the flight trainer. Parameters indicating piloting qualities and physiological functions of the pilot were recorded.</excerpt>

title: Autogenic training in the psycophysiological preparation for parachute jumps
doc: <title>Autogenic training in the psycophysiological preparation for parachute jumps</title>

title: Psychological states and aerobic fitness of male and female recruits before and after basic training
doc: <title>Psychological states and aerobic fitness of male and female recruits before and after basic training</title> <excerpt>Psychological states and aerobic fitness were measured using a battery of psychological tests and bicycle ergometer work test. A group of approximately two hundred male and female subjects were tested at the beginning of a six week basic training cycle and another group of two hundred were tested at the completion of basic training. A difference in mood, anxiety, self confidence and physical fitness was evident in the groups of male recruits, but not in the female recruits after training.</excerpt>

title: Case report of an obsessive-compulsive personality: A precursor to accident proneness
doc: <title>Case report of an obsessive-compulsive personality: A precursor to accident proneness</title> <excerpt>The social/physiological/psychological review of an aircraft accident involving input of incorrect controls and low-altitude ejection of a student naval aviator enlightened the investigators as to maybe a not-so-uncommon problem, accident proneness resulting from an obsessive-compulsive nonpsychotic personality. Review of the pilot's history reflected a perfectionist attitude since childhood with continuous associated near-serious accidents. Flight training revealed occurrences of over-correction, channelized attention, and denial of errors.</excerpt>

title: The human factor in the genesis and prevention of aeroplane accidents due to disorientation during flights; IL FATTORE UMANO NELLA GENESI E NELLA PREVENZIONE DEGLI INCIDENTI AEREI DOVUTI A DISORIENTAMENTO IN VOLO
doc: <title>The human factor in the genesis and prevention of aeroplane accidents due to disorientation during flights; IL FATTORE UMANO NELLA GENESI E NELLA PREVENZIONE DEGLI INCIDENTI AEREI DOVUTI A DISORIENTAMENTO IN VOLO</title> <excerpt>A certain number of accidents happening chiefly during phases of blind flights or during night flights may be caused or concurrently caused by the factor 'disorientation during flight', which is often due to illusory phenomena, dizziness, etc., derived from abnormal stimulation of the sense organs regulating the balance and spatial orientation, or from faultly coordination among the various perceptions concurring to orientation in the space. With the aim of preventing and reducing such flight accidents, it is very important for pilots to have a precise knowledge of the possible illusory phenomena appearing during flight as well as to be cognisant of their forecast and, finally, to be aware and be able to apply immediately adequate preventive measures enabling them to avoid the loss of orientation during the various flight conditions. Therefore the author has examined the most frequent circumstances and conditions which, during the aerial navigation on aircrafts - not only at fixed wing but also at rotating wing - may facilitate the pilot in his spatial disorientation favoring the occurrence of mental conflict when there is a sensorial incongruity amongst the various erroneous sensations coming from the vestibular apparatus and or from the perceptive organs and an inadequate visual information.</excerpt>

title: The mental confabulation in schizoid thought and in the error in flight; LA CONFABULAZIONE MENTALE NEL PENSIERO SCHIZOIDE E NELL'ERRORE IN VOLO
doc: <title>The mental confabulation in schizoid thought and in the error in flight; LA CONFABULAZIONE MENTALE NEL PENSIERO SCHIZOIDE E NELL'ERRORE IN VOLO</title> <excerpt>The undue synthesis of recodification at different levels and the pre-eminence of neurotic exciting areas are indicated as common characteristics of schizoidic thought and of errors in flight of the confabulatory type. An outline is given, therefore, of the possibility of prevention of the confabulatory error in flight by means of increasing the power of the inhibitory process..</excerpt>

title: Annoyance and Behavioral Aftereffects Following Interfering and Noninterfering Aircraft Noise
doc: <title>Annoyance and Behavioral Aftereffects Following Interfering and Noninterfering Aircraft Noise</title> <excerpt>This research involved experiments in effects of aircraft noise. In experiment 1, 120 subjects performed one of 2 tasks (listening or cancellation) within one of 3 auditory environments (continuous noise, intermittent noise, and quiet.) Aftereffects of noise on performance similar to those found by Glass and Singer in 1972 were not obtained. Subjects reported greater annoyance with noise when they worked on the listening task with which the noise interfered than they worked on the routine cancellation task where the noise did not interfere.</excerpt>

title: Results of sociologic research on the environmental problem of aircraft noise; SOZIALWISSENSCHAFTLICHE FORSCHUNGSERGEBNISSE ZUM UMWELTPROBLEM FLUGLARM
doc: <title>Results of sociologic research on the environmental problem of aircraft noise; SOZIALWISSENSCHAFTLICHE FORSCHUNGSERGEBNISSE ZUM UMWELTPROBLEM FLUGLARM</title> <excerpt>The GFR has over 400 airports, handling approx. 5 million flights annually; air traffic exposes the population to a considerable noise stress. In the USA, several European countries and Japan, numerous sociological studies have been carried out among persons living near airports to determine the effects of aircraft noise on human subjects.</excerpt>

title: Relevant MMPI Norms for Young Adult Air Force Trainees
doc: <title>Relevant MMPI Norms for Young Adult Air Force Trainees</title> <excerpt>The Air Force Medical Evaluation Test (AFMET) research program utilized the MMP1 in a psychological screening battery tor basic trainees. T-scores based on the Adult Norms seemed excessively elevated. The norms for Minnesota Adolescents were tried for the 17-year-old airmen.</excerpt>

title: INTERNATIONAL AIR SAFETY SEMINAR PROCEEDINGS, ANNUAL MEETING, 30TH: SAFETY NEEDS IN THE TERMINAL ENVIRONMENT, 1977.
doc: <title>INTERNATIONAL AIR SAFETY SEMINAR PROCEEDINGS, ANNUAL MEETING, 30TH: SAFETY NEEDS IN THE TERMINAL ENVIRONMENT, 1977.</title> <excerpt>Proceedings includes 24 papers covering the following topics: world jet experience; review of safety improvements over the last ten years; terminal area air traffic management; advanced terminal guidance and its capabilities; fuel consideration - the profile descent; terminal area weather/airport conditions forecast and communication; Transport Canada's runway traction and operational reporting system; airport bird hazard control; ramp hazards; matching the airport to operations and vice versa; airport disaster planning; airports and their effects on air carrier accidents; monitoring the approach; flight deck coordination; landing compulsion; shortcomings in understanding communications; psychology in communicating; the geriatric jet problem; and sources of published safety information..</excerpt>

title: Personality characteristics of pilot cadets with different marks in flying disciplines (Russian)
doc: <title>Personality characteristics of pilot cadets with different marks in flying disciplines (Russian)</title> <excerpt>The paper gives assessment of personality characteristics of pilot cadets and discusses their influence on the marks in flying disciplines. The study uses a discrimination analysis and presents a statistically optimal generalized criterion that can be applied to quantitative prediction of the success of flight training..</excerpt>

title: Age and the aviator: developing a psychophysiological proficiency index for pilots
doc: <title>Age and the aviator: developing a psychophysiological proficiency index for pilots</title>

title: Subjective stress assessment: a new, simple method to determine pilot workload
doc: <title>Subjective stress assessment: a new, simple method to determine pilot workload</title> <excerpt>Charged with the preparation of an expert opinion concerning psychophysical workload on pilots, the Aviation Psychology Branch of the GAF/IAM studied the 'Subjective Stress Assessment' in which 217 Army, Air Force and Navy pilots filled in a standardized questionnaire. This questionnaire included 170 items to force the pilots into rating their on- and off-duty life; the answers of these people (117 jet, 41 multiple-prop, 14 single-engine, and 45 helicopter pilots) were evaluated quantitatively and qualitatively It may be said - with all reservations towards subjectivity of pilots' opinions - that the pilots' image certainly requires some corrections, in particular as it relates to the ideal and material assessment of the activities of the separate groups of jet, helicopter, and prop pilots. It was the purpose of the study to show that the evaluation of pilots' workload by means of subjective interviews is a valuable method, aside from the assessment of difficulty of tasks by experts, aside from registration and evaluation of certain physiological parameters, and aside from the application of the Second-Task-Method-Registration..</excerpt>

title: Cross validation study of the personality aspects of involvement in pilot error accidents
doc: <title>Cross validation study of the personality aspects of involvement in pilot error accidents</title> <excerpt>Pilot error accidents have dominated accident statistics consistently from the 1940s to the present. In an earlier study the authors found that three factors from Cattell's Sixteen Personality Factor Questionnaire (16 PF) exhibited significant differences (p<0.05) between pilot error accident groups; these were used to correctly classify 86% of the aviators tested as to their previous pilot error accident involvement. There were 66 aviators given the 16 PF in the present study in an attempt to cross validate the findings reported in the original study.</excerpt>

title: An assessment of certain causal models used in surveys on aircraft noise annoyance
doc: <title>An assessment of certain causal models used in surveys on aircraft noise annoyance</title> <excerpt>The causal relationships which have so far been proposed between aircraft noise exposure, annoyance and certain "psycho-social" variables (fear of aircraft crashing, general attitude towards aviation, etc.), are re-analysed, and it is demonstrated that by using correlational analysis one can arrive at contradictory results. From the sociological surveys undertaken to date, one can derive only an ordered sequence of verbal reactions to aircraft noise, and not a causal sequence between these verbal reactions: the only clear cause of annoyance is the noise itself. It is suggested that future surveys on noise annoyance should include personality tests and health questionnaires, if one wishes to establish reliable causal sequences.</excerpt>

title: Significance of nonverbal characteristics of speech signals to assess the psychophysiological state of a pilot (Russian)
doc: <title>Significance of nonverbal characteristics of speech signals to assess the psychophysiological state of a pilot (Russian)</title> <excerpt>An analysis of the frequency, time and dynamics characteristics of the acoustic signal is one of the useful and reliable methods of objective assessment of the psychophysiological state of a pilot. The information conveyed through the nonverbal channel is nonspecific. The pattern of the stressor that causes a change in the pitch can be often identified only tentatively, if there is no additional information.</excerpt>

title: Cross-validation study of the personality aspects of involvement in pilot-error accidents
doc: <title>Cross-validation study of the personality aspects of involvement in pilot-error accidents</title> <excerpt>Pilot-error accidents have dominated accident statistics consistently from the 1940s to the present. Sanders and Hofmann (3) found that three factors from Cattell's Sixteen Personality Factor Questionnaire (16 PF) significant differences (p less than 0.05) between pilot-error accident groups and were used to correctly classify 86% of the aviators tested as to their previous pilot-error accident involvement. There were 66 aviators given the 16 PF in the present study in an attempt to cross-validate the findings reported in the original study.</excerpt>

title: Medical flying fitness--a routine affair--but who examines and assesses psychic health
doc: <title>Medical flying fitness--a routine affair--but who examines and assesses psychic health</title> <excerpt>The regular physiological check-up of pilots pretends to be a thorough diagnosis and yet the psychological aspects are ignored almost completely sometimes. As an excuse for this procedure, it is stated that in his psychological aptitude test prior to flying training, the pilot had already been classified as suitable and fit. It is hoped that this paper will show that the flying fitness examination procedure presently oriented towards the physical status of the individual is by no means sufficient to determine the actual degree of flying fitness.The regular physiological check-up of pilots pretends to be a thorough diagnosis and yet the psychological aspects are ignored almost completely sometimes.</excerpt>
