title: Variability in the emotional reactions of aviators before flight; VARIABILITE DES REACTIONS EMOTIONNELLES CHEZ LES AVIATEURS AVANT LE VOL
doc: <title>Variability in the emotional reactions of aviators before flight; VARIABILITE DES REACTIONS EMOTIONNELLES CHEZ LES AVIATEURS AVANT LE VOL</title> <excerpt>In 71 healthy aviators, aged 41.9 ± 5.1 yr, the biological state (response to stimuli, fusion point, ocular rheobase, pulse, blood pressure) is modified in comparison with the resting state. These variations are slightly different in the captains. They seem to be related to psychoemotional stress and aeronautical working conditions..</excerpt>

title: Factor Analysis of a New Multi-Dimensional Personality Questionnaire - A Check of the Factor Model in Comparison with Similar Methods.
doc: <title>Factor Analysis of a New Multi-Dimensional Personality Questionnaire - A Check of the Factor Model in Comparison with Similar Methods.</title> <excerpt>A personality inventory, the Temperament-Structure-Scales (TSS), was developed for the psychological selection of aviation personnel. The inventory includes questions about attitudes, behavior and biographical events. The results are reported and compared with a similar research on the 16 P.</excerpt>

title: Drug consumption as a reaction to environmental noise; Tablettenkonsum als Reaktion auf Lärm
doc: <title>Drug consumption as a reaction to environmental noise; Tablettenkonsum als Reaktion auf Lärm</title> <excerpt>Noise is considered as a tension inducing agent in the physical environment. Reaction to this stressor is by more internal or more external behavioral responses, depending on experience, resources and personality. Consumption of drugs is considered as an internalized behavioral response.</excerpt>

title: Relation between peer perception of leader behavior and instructor-pilot performance
doc: <title>Relation between peer perception of leader behavior and instructor-pilot performance</title> <excerpt>Studied the relationships between descriptions by peers of the leader behavior of 141 US Air Force instructor pilots and the performance of these pilots on several dimensions of proficiency. The Supervisory Behavior Description scores for Consideration and Structure were each found to be related to various criterion components and to the composite measure of proficiency, with all the relations positive. A multiple R of .50 was obtained by a combination of Consideration and Structure with the composite criterion.</excerpt>

title: Relationship between perceptual style and reactivity to motion
doc: <title>Relationship between perceptual style and reactivity to motion</title> <excerpt>The relationship between the perceptual-style dimension of field dependence-independence, as measured by the rod-and-frame test (RFT) and the group Hidden Figures Test, and motion disturbance, as evidenced by a version of the Brief Vestibular Disorientation Test (BVDT) was investigated in 83 naval aviation students. Significant correlations were found between RFT scores and BVDT scores. Field dependence was significantly associated with disturbance by the motion stimulus of the test.</excerpt>

doc: <title>From the history of the Central Psychophysiological Laboratory of the Military Aviation Unit; Iz istorii Tsental'noǐ psikhofiziologicheskoǐ laboratorii VVS</title>

title: Personality aspects of involvement in pilot error accidents
doc: <title>Personality aspects of involvement in pilot error accidents</title> <excerpt>The consistently high frequency of pilot error accidents in both military and civilian aviation programs does much to support exploratory research which might help alleviate the problem. Cattell's Sixteen Personality Factor Questionnaire (16 PF), Mehrabian Achievement Scale, and a dynamic decision making task (under risk) were given to 51 Army aviators. Accident files were then examined in order to classify the aviators as to their prior pilot error accident involvement.</excerpt>

title: Performance of air specialists after prolonged exposure to loud noise; EFFICIENZA PSICOFISICA DOPO ESPOSIZIONE PROLUNGATA AD INTENSI RUMORI IN PERSONALE SPECIALISTA DELL'AERONAUTICA MILITARE
doc: <title>Performance of air specialists after prolonged exposure to loud noise; EFFICIENZA PSICOFISICA DOPO ESPOSIZIONE PROLUNGATA AD INTENSI RUMORI IN PERSONALE SPECIALISTA DELL'AERONAUTICA MILITARE</title> <excerpt>Some psychological and psychophysiological tests (Toulouse Pieron attention test, critical flicker fusion, reaction times to visual stimuli) were performed on 20 Air Force specialists, assigned to aircraft maintenance and flight line attendance, professionally exposed to loud noise. Operational conditions submitted to investigation were: continuous exposure (1 1/2 hr) to noise (intensity: about 120 db); continuous exposure (5 hr) to background noise of 68-80 db with transient peaks at 90-115 db. Whenever requested, these specialists were equipped with collective or personal protective devices.</excerpt>

title: Motion sickness questionnaire and field independence scores as predictors of success in naval aviation training
doc: <title>Motion sickness questionnaire and field independence scores as predictors of success in naval aviation training</title> <excerpt>The present report has shown that a motion sickness questionnaire can be used to predict susceptibility to motion sickness or flight training success, depending on the items scored. There is a discussion of the theory that motion sickness results from conflicting preceptual inputs. This theory is related to aircraft operating conditions.</excerpt>

title: Reactions to sonic booms: A report of two studies and a general evaluation of startle effects
doc: <title>Reactions to sonic booms: A report of two studies and a general evaluation of startle effects</title> <excerpt>Two separate studies are reported. The first attempted to determine a sonic boom level below which startle would not occur. Subjects were exposed indoors to six simulated sonic booms having outside overpressures of 50, 30, and 16 N/m2 (inside levels of 74, 71, and 65 dBA).</excerpt>

title: The stress seekers: a psychological study of sports parachutists, racing drivers, and football players
doc: <title>The stress seekers: a psychological study of sports parachutists, racing drivers, and football players</title> <excerpt>Certain select men and women chose not only to participate, but to compete and often earn a living in sports that require consistent high level performance under conditions where great physiological and psychological pressures are exerted on the individual. This investigation deals with the assessment of personality characteristics for three select groups of such stress seeking men who compete at the highest levels in sports where the consequences of poor performance can be loss of job, emotional trauma, incapacitating injury, or death. 43 sport parachutists, 30 professional area racing drivers, and 50 professional football players were tested on three personality inventories (EPPS, MMPI, IPAT 16 PF).</excerpt>

title: Dynamics, diagnosis and disposition of two cases of skyjacking
doc: <title>Dynamics, diagnosis and disposition of two cases of skyjacking</title> <excerpt>The paper deals with two individuals diagnostically removed from each other, indicating that dynamically skyjackers cannot be placed over a common denominator. Thus, there does not exist a "Skyjacker Syndrome". Hopefully, air piracy will remain a short-lived episode in the history of aviation.</excerpt>

title: Additional heart rate - an indicator of psychological activation
doc: <title>Additional heart rate - an indicator of psychological activation</title> <excerpt>Heart rate and oxygen consumption of helicopter and transport aircraft pilots were measured. During flight operations, the heart rate accelerated without a corresponding increase in oxygen consumption. This heart rate increase beyond that expected from the oxygen uptake, ie additional heart rate, is therefore used as an indicator of psychological activation.</excerpt>

title: Psychophysiologic causes of flight accidents and safety measures in transport aviation (Russian)
doc: <title>Psychophysiologic causes of flight accidents and safety measures in transport aviation (Russian)</title> <excerpt>The paper discusses causes of flight accidents in relation to personality factors in pilots, crew members and ground staff. The psychophysiological mechanism of mistakes in an emergency situation is discussed. Safety measures are suggested..</excerpt>

title: Personality makeup of the American air traffic controller
doc: <title>Personality makeup of the American air traffic controller</title> <excerpt>Based on scores from the Sixteen Personality Factor Questionnaire, the personality structure of 11,047 persons working as air traffic controllers, and 9886 persons applying for that job, was examined through factor analytic and analysis of variance techniques. It was concluded that air traffic controllers are superior to the general population in all characteristics of personality essential to performance of their work and, further, that applicants for these positions are even better qualified in certain respects..</excerpt>

title: Personality differences between male and female air traffic controller applicants
doc: <title>Personality differences between male and female air traffic controller applicants</title> <excerpt>Differences in personality structure between 9,886 male and 217 female applicants for air traffic control positions were examined, using the Sixteen Personality Factor Questionnaire. Data were analyzed through the analysis of variance, and factor analytic techniques. It was shown through both methods that the personality structure of male and female applicants for these positions is much more similar than dissimilar..</excerpt>

title: Adjustment and maladjustment among basic flying course trainees - b ADAPTATION ET INADAPTATION EN ECOLE ELEMENTAIRE DE PILOTAGE
doc: <title>Adjustment and maladjustment among basic flying course trainees - b ADAPTATION ET INADAPTATION EN ECOLE ELEMENTAIRE DE PILOTAGE</title> <excerpt>A medical experience of nearly 3 yr leads the author to conclude that aviation clinical psychology plays an especially important role in the basic flying course A clear statement of its aims and methods is an essential prerequisite, for the purpose was not to introduce additional psychological criteria for selection, which would create a new category of reasons for failures besides medical, disciplinary or technical ones. Moreover the author considers these various categories somewhat artificially contrived, for they often mistake the effects for the causes. The distribution of these various 'causes' for failures may be modified fairly appreciably by a psycho pedagogically directed action.</excerpt>

title: Personality factors affecting motivation and selection for flying and continued flight proficiency
doc: <title>Personality factors affecting motivation and selection for flying and continued flight proficiency</title> <excerpt>Specific personality factors influence behavior in the air and flight security. Some are important in determining the drive to become a pilot. Others, such as ageing, interpersonal tensions and other forms of natural tension may practised to dangerous behavior in flight.</excerpt>

title: Experimental evaluation of annoyance and nuisance related to sleep disturbances by aircraft and traffic noises; EVALUATION EXPERIMENTALE DE LA GENE ET DE LA NUISANCE DES PERTURBATIONS DU SOMMEIL PAR DIVERS BRUITS DE CIRCULATION AUTOMOBILE ET AERIENNE
doc: <title>Experimental evaluation of annoyance and nuisance related to sleep disturbances by aircraft and traffic noises; EVALUATION EXPERIMENTALE DE LA GENE ET DE LA NUISANCE DES PERTURBATIONS DU SOMMEIL PAR DIVERS BRUITS DE CIRCULATION AUTOMOBILE ET AERIENNE</title> <excerpt>The influence, due to the characteristics of the noise, on the noise exposed people is considered. The advantages and inconveniences of studies done in the laboratory or in the home are discussed. The necessity of defining objective annoyance and health damage criteria in order to assess acceptable noise limits for housing and town planning is stressed..</excerpt>

title: Psycho therapy of flight personnel; PSYCHOTHERAPIE DES MEMBRES DU PERSONNEL NAVIGANT
doc: <title>Psycho therapy of flight personnel; PSYCHOTHERAPIE DES MEMBRES DU PERSONNEL NAVIGANT</title> <excerpt>The psycho therapy of flight personnel must take into account the particulars of their personalities and the requirements of their professional lives. The results of psycho therapeutic cures carried out over a period of 4 yr allow three categories to be distinguished in this type of treatment: 1) Long cures which generally involve cases almost no different from those found in other professions, para psychotic and neurotic syndromes, the profound etiology of which can be traced to disturbances in the psycho affective development during childhood. Here the incidence of professional factors is usually rather low.</excerpt>

title: Psychotechnical selection of flight personnel in South Vietnam; LA SELECTION PSYCHOTECHNIQUE DU PERSONNEL NAVIGANT AU SUD VIETNAM
doc: <title>Psychotechnical selection of flight personnel in South Vietnam; LA SELECTION PSYCHOTECHNIQUE DU PERSONNEL NAVIGANT AU SUD VIETNAM</title> <excerpt>Before a medical examination, 'pilot cadet' candidates underwent a psychotechnical selection procedure consisting of: 8 mental tests of the 'paper pencil' type : the CAT test (Cattell Intelligence Test), scale reading, auditive memory test, visual memory test, the PA test (Pattern Analysis), reading of coordinates and the MCT test (Mechanical Comprehension Test of Bennett). 6 psychomotor tests using different devices: the Diffused Attention device, the Omega apparatus, the Arsonval chronoscope, the stereometer, the Bourdanel optometric scale and Ishihara's series of pseudo isochromatic plates. 2 personality investigation methods: the Guilford Zimmermann questionnaire and the Heyer Courthial questionnaire.</excerpt>

title: Psychologic and psychopathologic aspects of behavior during airline pilot transition training
doc: <title>Psychologic and psychopathologic aspects of behavior during airline pilot transition training</title> <excerpt>Methods of retraining airline pilots in the transition from one type of aircraft to another are described. The anxieties produced in training are reported to be similar to those of physiological stress and gravitational stress. The International Air Transport Medical Committee's model transition training scheme is described, and is reported to have effected a reduction in the pilots' liability to symptoms of stress.</excerpt>

title: Functions of a psychotherapist in aviation medicine; AUFGABEN EINES PSYCHOTHERAPEUTEN IN DER LUFTFAHRTMEDIZIN
doc: <title>Functions of a psychotherapist in aviation medicine; AUFGABEN EINES PSYCHOTHERAPEUTEN IN DER LUFTFAHRTMEDIZIN</title> <excerpt>Expert opinions on fitness are limited to diagnostic measures. Foremost are difficulties in personality diagnosis. Psychotherapeutic consulting hours were mainly frequented by management staff and personnel of the technical range.</excerpt>

title: Need satisfaction in the identification of the DOR
doc: <title>Need satisfaction in the identification of the DOR</title> <excerpt>The purpose of the present study was to determine whether student pilots who voluntarily drop from the program (DORs) and those who successfully complete training enter the flight program with different 'needs', and whether DORs and 'completers' differ in their evaluation of the program's ability to satisfy their needs. The needs that were explored were those of the Maslow hierarchy, including physiological, safety, and security, social, self esteem, and self actualization needs. Eighty seven aviation officer candidates were given a questionnaire designed to measure optimism, relevance, and importance in terms of the five needs described above.</excerpt>

title: Functions, meaning and examination techniques in aviation ophthalmology; AUFGABEN, BEDEUTUNG UND UNTERSUCHUNGSTECHNIK IN DER LUFTFAHRTOPHTHALMOLOGIE
doc: <title>Functions, meaning and examination techniques in aviation ophthalmology; AUFGABEN, BEDEUTUNG UND UNTERSUCHUNGSTECHNIK IN DER LUFTFAHRTOPHTHALMOLOGIE</title> <excerpt>In aviation medicine the ophthalmologist must have good clinical and practical experience, and, in addition to this, interest in ophthalmological psychophysiology. He must be versed in general aviation medicine, and must know the effects of oxygen deficiency (anoxia), of linear variations of pressure and of angular acceleration on the visual system. Knowledge of occupational medicine is also demanded when taking care of the licensees.</excerpt>

doc: <title>Psychosomatic disturbances in air traffic controllers; LES TROUBLES PSYCHOSOMATIQUES CHEZ LES CONTROLEURS DE LA CIRCULATION AERIENNE</title> <excerpt>The findings in 192 air traffic controllers are discussed. This group presents a rich symptomatology, in which psychosomatic affections are frequently involved. These affections are classified.</excerpt>

title: Comparison of the job attitudes of personnel in three air traffic control specialties
doc: <title>Comparison of the job attitudes of personnel in three air traffic control specialties</title> <excerpt>A total of 792 journeyman air traffic controllers from ARTCC, TRACON, and FSS facilities answered a four part questionnaire concerning what they liked and disliked about ATC work, how much they liked or disliked certain specific aspects of ATC work, how they felt about shift work, and their level of job satisfaction. In general, the three ATC specialties showed high agreement in their job related attitudes. They liked most of their job tasks and the challenge of ATC work; they tended to dislike management, their work schedules, and job tasks not directly related to traffic control or flight service.</excerpt>

title: Psychodiagnostic investigations among a group of aircraft pilots; INDAGINI PSICODIAGNOSTICHE SU UN GRUPPO DI PILOTI MILITARI
doc: <title>Psychodiagnostic investigations among a group of aircraft pilots; INDAGINI PSICODIAGNOSTICHE SU UN GRUPPO DI PILOTI MILITARI</title> <excerpt>An extensive psychodiagnostic study was carried out with 15 aircraft pilots submitted to Rorschach's test. The results were carefully compared with those pertaining to 15 non military pilots and with 15 civilians having the same characteristics of the pilots as far as sex, age and culture are concerned. The pilots are somewhat more intelligent (intelligence of a theoretical type), spiritually more mature and richer of interior life and affective sociability when compared with the normal average.</excerpt>

title: The flying teams as a means of organizing psychiatric and social aid in an isolated rural district; LES EQUIPES VOLANTES, MOYEN D'ORGANISER DES SOINS PSYCHIATRIQUES ET COMMUNAUTAIRES DANS UNE REGION RURALE ET ISOLEE
doc: <title>The flying teams as a means of organizing psychiatric and social aid in an isolated rural district; LES EQUIPES VOLANTES, MOYEN D'ORGANISER DES SOINS PSYCHIATRIQUES ET COMMUNAUTAIRES DANS UNE REGION RURALE ET ISOLEE</title> <excerpt>Following a brief review of the literature the article describes the deployment of psychiatric teams in isolated, deprived, rural areas. The visiting teams were put into operation according to the principles of community psychiatry and were acting mostly as consultants to the local resources. In a little more than a year, 1608 files were started, 25% of this number being for children.</excerpt>

title: Personality differences among men in selected Air Force specialties
doc: <title>Personality differences among men in selected Air Force specialties</title> <excerpt>Notes that job placement based on aptitude has provided the human resources necessary to perform the U.S. Air Force mission but has not produced a work force that is satisfied with the duty assignments. A consideration of enlistee personality and interests might refine this job placement system.</excerpt>

title: Innovations in training: The New Aviation Scientist--Psychologist and Engineer
doc: <title>Innovations in training: The New Aviation Scientist--Psychologist and Engineer</title> <excerpt>Notes that meaningful research in applied experimental psychology is often conducted as an interdisciplinary effort. This approach is especially prevalent in aviation because particular consideration must be given to human capabilities and limitations in the aircraft system design process. This article describes the Aviation Research Laboratory at the Institute of Aviation of the University of Illinois, which provides a unique environment for graduate training in aviation research.</excerpt>

Ss were lower in trait anxiety and higher in state anxiety than a group of 253 previously tested male college students. However, with an induced anxiety act, both state and trait anxiety scores were significantly lower than the scores obtained during the initial administration of the test.</excerpt>

title: The Kennedy airport snown: An inquiry into intergroup phenomena
doc: <title>The Kennedy airport snown: An inquiry into intergroup phenomena</title> <excerpt>Disaster may serve as a paradigm for examining the complex interplay of many of the factors that influence human behavior. Within the context of the disaster, the interaction of such factors as individual psychodynamics, small group processes, and intergroup dynamics can be examined.1 This paper deals with an existential and theoretical account of a particular disaster, the Kennedy Airport Snow-In of February, 1969, which may in some way illustrate behavioral phenomena common to events of this type. The empirical data derive from one of the authors, who was an affected passenger (C.A.H.).2 The gathering of data of a non personal nature, the integration of the collected information, and the conclusions drawn about intergroup phenomena presume a distance from the initial confusion.</excerpt>

title: Disaster alert and the community mental health center
doc: <title>Disaster alert and the community mental health center</title> <excerpt>Hospitals must be prepared for disasters of indeterminate magnitude in order to fulfill their community function. The protocol for organization of services should be brief, explicit, and define who is in charge of duty assignments. Psychiatrists are uniquely prepared to handle telephone calls from distraught relatives.</excerpt>

doc: <title>Steepness of approach and avoidance gradient in humans as a function of experience: Theory and experiment</title> <excerpt>33 experienced and 33 novice parachutists rated their approach and avoidance feelings at different points in time preceding and following a parachute jump. For the novices self-rated avoidance increased up to a point shortly before the jump, and then decreased. For the experienced Ss self-rated avoidance increased up to the morning of the jump, decreased to the jump, and increased after the jump.</excerpt>

doc: <title>Schematic Simulation: A Technique for the Design and Development of a Complex System</title> <excerpt>Schematic simulation is the name of a method for studying system specifications and explicating implications of the specifications for subsystem design. The method was developed in response to the expressed need of the designers of a Terminal Air Traffic Control (TATC) laboratory system. The method provides a model of the projected system and a procedure by which the designers can view system operations from the standpoint of the eventual operators.</excerpt>

title: Aircraft conspicuity and flight attitude information provided by exterior paint patterns
doc: <title>Aircraft conspicuity and flight attitude information provided by exterior paint patterns</title> <excerpt>Experiments were conducted to determine the relative conspicuity of aircraft exterior paint patterns, and to investigate whether such paint patterns aided pilots in determining the attitude of the aircraft. The conspicuity studies, using paired comparisons of model airplanes, gave evidence that: (a) amount of red-orange fluorescent paint coverage is positively correlated with conspicuity; (b) high brightness paints should be placed on the upper surfaces of the aircraft and low brightness paints on the lower portions; (c) maximizing brightness contrasts between different parts of the aircraft surfaces does not enhance conspicuity; (d) flight attitudes, backgrounds, lighting conditions, and differences in Ss did not affect conspicuity significantly. The attitude studies in which pilots matched the model airplanes in some 1 of 15 attitudes, with 1 of 15 models mounted on a small display, indicated that the paint patterns used did not aid the pilots in making judgments of aircraft attitude.</excerpt>

doc: <title>Attitudes toward authority-figures as correlates of motivation among Naval Aviation Cadets</title> <excerpt>To explore the relationship between attitudes toward authority figures and motivation, 65 "high" motivation aviation cadets (successfully completed basic flight training) and 72 "low" motivation cadets (voluntary withdrawals from flight training) completed an anonymous questionnaire calling for a sample of behavior characteristic of their "best" instructor and a sample descriptive of the "worst" instructor. 5 content categories were identified for the "best" instructor, and three for the "worst" instructor statements. title: The factorial composition of two tests of comprehension in reading

doc: <title>History, organization and research activities, Psychological Research Project (Navigator), Army Air Forces</title> <excerpt>The ninth in a series of reports describing the Aviation Psychology Program of the Army Air Forces, this article covers the work of the application of psychological and statistical techniques to research in navigation. It deals with the following points: (1) objective measures of skill in navigation; (2) research in training; (3) research on the selection of instructors; and (4) work in the Navigation Schools. A list of personnel attached to this project is given.</excerpt>

title: Present organization, policies and research activities of the AAF Aviation Psychology Program
doc: <title>Present organization, policies and research activities of the AAF Aviation Psychology Program</title> <excerpt>This report is the eighth in a series describing the AAF aviation psychology program. The article describes the organization and functions of this program as of June, 1945. The basic research policies and postulates of the program are given, together with a report of the research mission.</excerpt>

title: Psychological activities in the Training Command, Army Air Forces
doc: <title>Psychological activities in the Training Command, Army Air Forces</title> <excerpt>The development of the Aviation Psychology Program in the AAF Training Command since an earlier report in 1943 (see 18: 1497) is treated, consisting largely of a report of the activities of the Psychological Section, Medical Division, Headquarters, AAF Training Command. The report is made under the following headings: mission of the section; organization and personnel; supervision of classification testing and processing; maintenance of basic data; development and validation of devices for predicting aircrew success; application of the classification test battery to other groups; training research problems; special research studies; publications; and prospectus. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).</excerpt>

title: Clinical research in the Aviation Psychology Program of the Army Air Forces
doc: <title>Clinical research in the Aviation Psychology Program of the Army Air Forces</title> <excerpt>During the past year there has been increased emphasis on the problems of training methods, instructor selection, selection of flying personnel for key positions in combat, and redistribution of returnees. Several significant studies utilizing clinical psychological methods are described in this report. These are discussed under the following headings: case studies of pilots in training, clinical evaluation of aviation trainees, projective techniques, and adjustment after combat.</excerpt>

title: History, organization, and research activities, Psychological Test Film Unit, Army Air Forces
doc: <title>History, organization, and research activities, Psychological Test Film Unit, Army Air Forces</title> <excerpt>The history, organization, personnel and research activities of the Unit at the Santa Ana Army Air Base, Santa Ana, California, are presented. The following topics are also discussed: (1) hypotheses adopted for perceptual test development, (2) techniques employed in test construction, and (3) test construction. A separate section deals with selected research activities not covered in the above classifications.</excerpt>

title: Research program on psychomotor tests in the Army Air Forces
doc: <title>Research program on psychomotor tests in the Army Air Forces</title> <excerpt>The research activities are reported of Psychological Research Unit (PRU) No. 2, San Antonio Aviation Cadet Center, San Antonio, Texas, and of the Department of Psychology, Research Section, School of Aviation Medicine, Randolph Field, Texas. The organization and personnel of both of these units are described, and a list of personnel (officer and enlisted) of PRU No.</excerpt>

title: The Aviation Psychology Program of the Army Air Forces
doc: <title>The Aviation Psychology Program of the Army Air Forces</title> <excerpt>This is the first of a series describing the Aviation Psychology Program. It deals with the general organization and historical development up to October 1943, giving the locations of centers and personnel and a description of the testing program and schedule. The tests fall into these types: (1) intelligence, judgment, and proficiency, (2) alertness, observation, and speed of perception, and (3) visual-motor co-ordination.</excerpt>

title: Utilization of psychologists in the United States Navy
doc: <title>Utilization of psychologists in the United States Navy</title> <excerpt>Utilization of psychologists by the Navy falls under 3 heads: (1) construction, administration, and interpretation of tests; (2) interviewing, ranging from employment to clinical; (3) special services, covering a wide variety of tasks requiring psychological skills. Psychologists have been commissioned in 4 categories with various rank titles. Most of the article describes the duties of the H-V(S) [Hospital-Volunteer Reserve (Special Service)], which aids in the selection of aviation cadets.</excerpt>
